To determine the capital, I will reference my knowledge of U.S. state capitals. The options provided are (A) Salem, (B) Olympia, (C) Portland, and (D) Carson City. Among these, Salem is the capital of Oregon.

1411.question: What is the temperature of a hot day in the desert?
1411.subject: natural science
1411.lecture:
Measurements are written with both a number and a unit. The unit comes after the number. The unit shows what the number means.
Temperature can be written with units of degrees Fahrenheit (°F) or Celsius (°C). Use the list below to compare the two units.
212°F | Water boils | 100°C
98.6°F | Body temperature | 37°C
68°F | Room temperature | 20°C
32°F | Water freezes | 0°C
1411.solution:
The better estimate for the temperature of a hot day in the desert is 45°C.
45°F is too cold.

1412.question: Which animal is also adapted to be camouflaged in the snow?
1412.hint:
Polar bears live in and around the cold Arctic Ocean. The  is adapted to be camouflaged in the snow.
Figure: polar bear.
1412.subject: natural science
1412.skill: Animal adaptations: skins and body coverings
1412.lecture:
An adaptation is an inherited trait that helps an organism survive or reproduce. Adaptations can include both body parts and behaviors.
The color, texture, and covering of an animal's skin are examples of adaptations. Animals' skins can be adapted in different ways. For example, skin with thick fur might help an animal stay warm. Skin with sharp spines might help an animal defend itself against predators.
1412.solution:
Look at the picture of the polar bear.
The polar bear has white fur covering its body. It is adapted to be camouflaged in the snow. The word camouflage means to blend in.
Now look at each animal. Figure out which animal has a similar adaptation.
During the winter, the Arctic hare has white fur covering its body. It is adapted to be camouflaged in the snow.
The camel has sand-colored fur covering its skin. It is not adapted to be camouflaged in the snow.

1413.question: What is the capital of Colorado?
1413.subject: social science
1413.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will first analyze the image to identify the highlighted state, confirm its identity as Colorado, and then select its capital from the given options.

The image depicts a map of the United States with the state of Colorado highlighted in a darker shade. The rest of the states are shown in a lighter color.
1413.solution:
The image highlights the state of Colorado on the U.S. map. The question asks for the capital of Colorado. From the options provided, I need to select the correct capital city. Colorado's capital is Denver. The options given are: 
(A) Saint Paul 
(B) Colorado Springs 
(C) Denver 
(D) Juneau 
Since Denver is the correct capital of Colorado, I will choose option C.

1414.question: What is the direction of this push?
1414.hint: Two friends are out in a park. One man walks. He uses a force to push the other man's wheelchair with his hands.
1414.subject: natural science
1414.lecture:
A force is a push or a pull that one object applies to another. Every force has a direction.
The direction of a push is away from the object that is pushing.
The direction of a pull is toward the object that is pulling.
1414.solution: The walking man pushes the wheelchair. The direction of the push is away from his hands.

1415.question: What information supports the conclusion that Steve acquired this trait?
choices: Steve likes to look at butterflies and beetles.
Steve learned to identify insects by reading many books about insects.
1415.hint:
Read the description of a trait.
Steve is good at identifying insects.
1415.subject: natural science
1415.skill: Inherited and acquired traits: use evidence to support a statement
1415.lecture:
Organisms, including people, have both inherited and acquired traits. Inherited and acquired traits are gained in different ways.
Inherited traits are passed down through families. Children gain these traits from their parents. Inherited traits do not need to be learned.
Acquired traits are gained during a person's life. Some acquired traits, such as riding a bicycle, are gained by learning. Other acquired traits, such as scars, are caused by the environment.

1416.question: Compare the motion of two speed walkers. Which speed walker was moving at a higher speed?
choices: a speed walker who moved 50miles in 10hours
a speed walker who moved 25miles in 10hours
1416.subject: natural science
1416.skill: Compare the speeds of moving objects
1416.lecture:
An object's speed tells you how fast the object is moving. Speed depends on both distance and time.
Distance tells you how far the object has moved. One unit used to measure distance is the mile.
Time tells you how long the object has spent moving. One unit used to measure time is the hour.
Think about two objects moving for the same amount of time. The object that is moving faster will go a farther distance in that time. It is moving at a higher speed.
1416.solution:
Look at the distance each speed walker moved and the time it took to move that distance.
One speed walker moved 50 miles in 10 hours.
The other speed walker moved 25 miles in 10 hours.
Notice that each speed walker spent the same amount of time moving. The speed walker who moved 50 miles moved a farther distance in that time. So, that speed walker must have moved at a higher speed.

1417.question: Which of the following could Dakota's test show?
choices: if the blade guards would break in a crash
how much the drone weighed with the blade guards
if adding the blade guards made the drone fly poorly
1417.hint:
People can use the engineering-design process to develop solutions to problems. One step in the process is testing if a potential solution meets the requirements of the design.
The passage below describes how the engineering-design process was used to test a solution to a problem. Read the passage. Then answer the question below.

Dakota was designing small aircraft called drones to pick up items from warehouse shelves. She knew that the drones' propeller blades would get damaged if they bumped into anything while flying through the warehouse. So, Dakota wanted to add blade guards to protect the propeller blades. The guards had to be sturdy so they would not break in a crash. But she thought that if the guards weighed too much, the drones would not fly well.
So, Dakota put guards made of lightweight metal on one drone. Then she observed how well the drone flew with the guards.
Figure: a drone without blade guards.
1417.subject: natural science
1417.lecture:
People can use the engineering-design process to develop solutions to problems. One step in the process is testing if a potential solution meets the requirements of the design. How can you determine what a test can show? You need to figure out what was tested and what was measured.
Imagine an engineer needs to design a bridge for a windy location. She wants to make sure the bridge will not move too much in high wind. So, she builds a smaller prototype, or model, of a bridge. Then, she exposes the prototype to high winds and measures how much the bridge moves.
First, identify what was tested. A test can examine one design, or it may compare multiple prototypes to each other. In the test described above, the engineer tested a prototype of a bridge in high wind.
Then, identify what the test measured. One of the criteria for the bridge was that it not move too much in high winds. The test measured how much the prototype bridge moved.
Tests can show how well one or more designs meet the criteria. The test described above can show whether the bridge would move too much in high winds.

1418.question: Select the amphibian.
1418.subject: natural science
1418.skill: Identify mammals, birds, fish, reptiles, and amphibians
1418.lecture: Amphibians have moist skin and begin their lives in water.
1418.solution:
A hammerhead shark is a fish. It lives underwater. It has fins, not limbs.
Hammerhead sharks get their names from the shape of their heads. They have a wide, flat head and a small mouth.
A green chameleon is a reptile. It has scaly, waterproof skin.
Chameleons eat insects. They use their long, sticky tongues to catch their prey.
A western toad is an amphibian. It has moist skin and begins its life in water.
Toads do not have teeth! They swallow their food whole.
A Banggai cardinalfish is a fish. It lives underwater. It has fins, not limbs.
Cardinalfish often live near coral reefs. They are nocturnal, which means that they are active mostly at night.

1419.question: Select the one true statement.
choices: The cytoplasm of an animal cell is inside the cell membrane.
The vacuoles of an animal cell use sunlight to make sugar.
The cell membrane directs cell activities by sending instructions to different parts of an animal cell.
1419.subject: natural science

1420.question: The United States has a federal system. Based on these definitions, which of these statements would most likely be made by a person who lives under a federal system?
choices: My national government officials decide most issues that come up.
Both my state and national government officials have power over important issues.
I only pay attention to state politics since the national government has almost no power.
1420.hint:
Think about the name of the United States of America. As the name shows, the country has both a united national government and a collection of state governments. In the following questions, you will learn about the relationship between the national government and state governments. You will also learn about how state and local governments work.
Many countries have both a national government and state governments. However, these countries divide power differently between the national and state governments. The table below describes three different systems for dividing power. Look at the table. Then answer the question below.
1420.subject: social science
1420.lecture:
To solve this problem, I will analyze the table to identify characteristics of a federal system and then match those attributes to the statements provided to determine which one is most likely made by someone in such a system.

The image is a table with three columns: System of government, Amount of power given to national government, and Definition. It categorizes government systems into Unitary, Federal, and Confederate, with explanations about the distribution of power between national and state governments.
1420.solution: The federal system is described as having a middle level of power distribution, where both the national government and state governments share power. In contrast, the unitary system gives most power to the national government, and the confederate system grants most power to the states. Among the options, statement (B) indicates a power-sharing arrangement where both state and national government officials have power over important issues. This aligns with the definition of a federal system. Statement (A) suggests that the national government decides most issues, resembling a unitary system, while statement (C) implies national government insignificance, akin to a confederate system.

1421.question: What information supports the conclusion that Maureen inherited this trait?
choices: Maureen's parents were born with wavy hair. They passed down this trait to Maureen.
Maureen and her mother both have short hair.
1421.hint:
Read the description of a trait.
Maureen has wavy hair.
1421.subject: natural science
1421.skill: Inherited and acquired traits: use evidence to support a statement
1421.lecture:
Organisms, including people, have both inherited and acquired traits. Inherited and acquired traits are gained in different ways.
Inherited traits are passed down from biological parents to their offspring through genes. Genes are pieces of hereditary material that contain the instructions that affect inherited traits. Offspring receive their genes, and therefore gain their inherited traits, from their biological parents. Inherited traits do not need to be learned.
Acquired traits are gained during a person's life. Some acquired traits, such as riding a bicycle, are gained by learning. Other acquired traits, such as scars, are caused by the environment. Parents do not pass acquired traits down to their offspring.

1422.question: Is a strawberry a good or a service?
1422.subject: social science
1422.lecture:
Everything you can buy is either a good or a service.
A good is something you can touch or hold in your hands. For example, a hammer is a good.
A service is a job you pay someone else to do. For example, cooking food in a restaurant is a service.
1422.solution:
To decide whether a strawberry is a good or a service, ask these questions:
Is a strawberry something you can touch? Yes.
Is a strawberry a job you might pay someone else to do? No.
So, a strawberry is a good.

1423.question:
Complete the text to describe the diagram.
Solute particles moved in both directions across the permeable membrane. But more solute particles moved across the membrane (). When there was an equal concentration on both sides, the particles reached equilibrium.
choices: to the right than to the left
to the left than to the right
1423.hint:
The diagram below shows a solution with one solute. Each solute particle is represented by a purple ball. The solution fills a closed container that is divided in half by a membrane. The membrane, represented by a dotted line, is permeable to the solute particles.
The diagram shows how the solution can change over time during the process of diffusion.
1423.subject: natural science
1423.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will examine the image to determine the direction of solute particle movement across the membrane, which leads to equilibrium. Then, I will use this information to select the correct option.

The image shows a container divided into two sections by a permeable membrane. Initially, there are six purple solute particles on the left side and two on the right side. After diffusion, there are four solute particles on each side, indicating an equal concentration.
1423.solution: Initially, the higher concentration of solute particles is on the left side (six particles) compared to the right side (two particles). Diffusion occurs, causing particles to move from the area of higher concentration to the area of lower concentration. As a result, more particles move from left to right, resulting in an equal distribution of four particles per side. This establishes equilibrium because the concentrations are now equal. Therefore, more solute particles moved across the membrane to the right than to the left.

1424.question: Compare the average kinetic energies of the particles in each sample. Which sample has the higher temperature?
choices: neither; the samples have the same temperature
1424.hint: The diagrams below show two pure samples of gas in identical closed, rigid containers. Each colored ball represents one gas particle. Both samples have the same number of particles.
1424.subject: natural science
1424.skill: Identify how particle motion affects temperature and pressure
1424.lecture:
To determine which sample has the higher temperature, I will compare the average kinetic energies of the particles in each sample, considering both their mass and speed. This will indicate which sample has the higher temperature.

The image shows two jars labeled Sample A and Sample B. Sample A contains green particles, each with a mass of 30 u and an average speed of 1,100 m/s. Sample B contains blue particles, each with a mass of 20 u and an average speed of 1,000 m/s. Both samples have the same number of particles in identical containers.
1424.solution:
The temperature of a substance is determined by the average kinetic energy of its particles. The kinetic energy (KE) can be calculated using the formula: KE = 0.5 * m * v², where m is mass and v is speed. Since both samples have the same number of particles, I only need to consider the average kinetic energy of individual particles.

1. Calculate the average kinetic energy for a particle in Sample A: 
\[ KE_A = 0.5 * 30\, \text{u} * (1,100\, \text{m/s})². \]

2. Calculate the average kinetic energy for a particle in Sample B:
\[ KE_B = 0.5 * 20\, \text{u} * (1,000\, \text{m/s})². \]

3. Compare the kinetic energies. Given that both mass and speed are higher in Sample A, the particles in Sample A have higher kinetic energy than those in Sample B.

Thus, since Sample A has higher average kinetic energy, it must have a higher temperature.

1425.question:
Which tense does the sentence use?
Brad invited Sofia to his house.
1425.subject: language science
1425.skill: Is the sentence in the past, present, or future tense?
1425.lecture:
Present tense verbs tell you about something that is happening now.
Most present-tense verbs are regular. They have no ending, or they end in -s or -es.
Two verbs are irregular in the present tense, to be and to have. You must remember their forms.
Past tense verbs tell you about something that has already happened.
Most past-tense verbs are regular. They end in -ed.
Some verbs are irregular in the past tense. You must remember their past-tense forms.
Future tense verbs tell you about something that is going to happen.
All future-tense verbs use the word will.
Present | Past | Future
walk, walks | walked | will walk
go, goes | went | will go
1425.solution: The sentence is in past tense. You can tell because it uses a past-tense verb, invited. The verb ends in -ed and tells you about something that has already happened.

1426.question: What is the capital of Iowa?
1426.subject: social science
1426.skill: Identify state capitals of the Midwest
1426.lecture:
I will identify the highlighted state on the map as Iowa and then determine its capital from the given options.

The image shows a map of the United States with all states in light green. One state, located in the Midwest, is highlighted in a darker green color. This state is Iowa.
1426.solution: The highlighted state on the map of the United States is Iowa. To find the capital of Iowa, I will review the provided options: (A) Cedar Rapids, (B) Frankfort, (C) Des Moines, and (D) Davenport. From these, I identify that Des Moines is the capital of Iowa. Thus, the correct answer among the options is Des Moines, option C.

1427.question: Which of the following contains a vague pronoun reference?
choices: Scott washed the windshield of his car even though he knew it would just get dirty again.
Scott washed the windshield of his car even though he knew the car would just get dirty again.
1427.subject: language science
1427.lecture:
When writing, make sure to avoid vague pronoun references. A vague pronoun reference occurs when a pronoun could refer to more than one possible antecedent.
When Lisa and Kim finally landed, she breathed a sigh of relief.
The pronoun she could refer to either Lisa or Kim, so the meaning of the sentence is unclear.
Vague pronoun references can be corrected in one of two ways:
1. Replace the pronoun with its correct antecedent:
When Lisa and Kim finally landed, Lisa breathed a sigh of relief.
2. Rewrite the sentence:
Lisa breathed a sigh of relief when she and Kim finally landed.
A vague pronoun reference also occurs when they, them, their, theirs, it, or its is used without its antecedent.
They say that this nail polish dries in less than five minutes.
The pronoun they is used without its antecedent, so the meaning of the sentence is unclear.
This problem can be fixed by replacing the pronoun with its missing antecedent.
The advertisements say that this nail polish dries in less than five minutes.
1427.solution:
The second answer choice contains a vague pronoun reference. The pronoun it could refer to the windshield or the car.
The first answer choice shows a possible correction for the vague pronoun reference. It has been replaced with the car.
Scott washed the windshield of his car even though he knew the car would just get dirty again.

1430.question: Which of the following could Aisha and Lily's test show?
choices: if a new batch of concrete was firm enough to use
if the concrete from each batch took the same amount of time to dry
1430.hint:
People can use the engineering-design process to develop solutions to problems. One step in the process is testing if a potential solution meets the requirements of the design.
The passage below describes how the engineering-design process was used to test a solution to a problem. Read the passage. Then answer the question below.

Aisha and Lily were making batches of concrete for a construction project. To make the concrete, they mixed together dry cement powder, gravel, and water. Then, they checked if each batch was firm enough using a test called a slump test.
They poured some of the fresh concrete into an upside-down metal cone. They left the concrete in the metal cone for 30 seconds. Then, they lifted the cone to see if the concrete stayed in a cone shape or if it collapsed. If the concrete in a batch collapsed, they would know the batch should not be used.
Figure: preparing a concrete slump test.
1430.subject: natural science
1430.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will analyze the image and description of the slump test to understand what Aisha and Lily are testing. I will then relate this understanding to the provided options to determine which one aligns with the test's purpose.

The image shows two people conducting a slump test on concrete. They are pouring the concrete into an upside-down metal cone and then lifting the cone to observe whether the concrete holds its shape or collapses.
1430.solution: The slump test is described as a method for assessing the firmness of concrete. The concrete is poured into a cone, and after the cone is lifted, the observation is made to see if the concrete stays in a cone shape or collapses. This procedure determines if the concrete is firm enough for use. The options provided are: (A) if a new batch of concrete was firm enough to use, and (B) if the concrete from each batch took the same amount of time to dry. The described process specifically tests the firmness of the concrete by checking if it maintains its shape, which directly corresponds to option A. Option B does not relate to what the slump test measures.

1431.question: Which ocean is highlighted?
1431.subject: social science
1431.lecture: Oceans are huge bodies of salt water. The world has five oceans. All of the oceans are connected, making one world ocean.

1432.question:
Which figure of speech is used in this text?
At twenty-one, Bruce felt overwhelmed with adult responsibilities and wished he could fly off to Neverland.
1432.subject: language science
1432.lecture:
Figures of speech are words or phrases that use language in a nonliteral or unusual way. They can make writing more expressive.
Alliteration is the repetition of sounds at the beginning of nearby words.
What a lucky little lady you are!
An allusion is a brief reference to something or someone well known, often from history or literature.
"I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!" Lila remarked.
An idiom is an expression that cannot be understood literally. Its meaning must be learned.
The assignment was a piece of cake.
A simile uses like or as to compare two things that are not actually alike.
The cat's fur was as dark as the night.
A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.
The snow formed a blanket over the town.
Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.
The scrambled eggs hit the floor with a splat.
Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.
The trees danced in the wind.
A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.
A great new broom is sweeping the nation.
Verbal irony involves saying one thing but implying something very different. People often use verbal irony when they are being sarcastic.
Olivia seems thrilled that her car keeps breaking down.
Each breakdown is as enjoyable as a punch to the face.
1432.solution:
The text uses an allusion, a brief reference to someone or something well known.
Neverland alludes to the story of Peter Pan, a boy who lived in Neverland and never grew up.

1433.question:
What does the euphemism in this text suggest?
Will is big-boned, so despite being in middle school, he often shops in the men's department.
choices: Will has larger bones than most people.
1433.subject: language science
1433.lecture:
Figures of speech are words or phrases that use language in a nonliteral or unusual way. They can make writing more expressive.
A euphemism is a polite or indirect expression that is used to de-emphasize an unpleasant topic.
The head of Human Resources would never refer to firing people, only to laying them off.
1433.solution:
The text uses a euphemism, a polite or indirect expression that is used to de-emphasize an unpleasant topic.
The euphemism big-boned suggests that Will is overweight.

1434.question: Identify the question that Lola's experiment can best answer.
choices: Do slugs eat more from tomato leaves or broccoli leaves?
Do slugs weigh more after eating tomato leaves or broccoli leaves?
1434.hint:
The passage below describes an experiment. Read the passage and then follow the instructions below.

Lola cut tomato and broccoli plant leaves into one-inch squares. In each of 12 containers, she placed six leaf squares: three tomato-leaf squares and three broccoli-leaf squares. She put one slug from her garden into each container. After two days, Lola measured the amount of each leaf square that had been eaten by the slugs. She compared the amount that had been eaten from the tomato-leaf squares to the amount that had been eaten from the broccoli-leaf squares.
Figure: a slug on a leaf.
1434.subject: natural science
1434.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will identify what was tested and measured in Lola's experiment. By determining these two aspects, I can match the experiment to the most appropriate question it answers.

The image shows a slug on a leaf, which relates to Lola's experiment that involves observing slugs eating leaf squares from tomato and broccoli plants.
1434.solution:
First, I'll identify what was tested in Lola's experiment. Lola placed slugs in containers with leaf squares of tomato and broccoli plants. This suggests she is testing the slugs' feeding preference between the two types of leaves.

Next, I'll identify what was measured. Lola measured the amount eaten from each type of leaf square after two days. This indicates she is comparing the quantity consumed from each type.

Now, I'll determine which of the choices reflects testing feeding preference and measuring the amount eaten. Option (A) asks whether slugs eat more from tomato leaves or broccoli leaves. It directly relates to measuring which leaves are eaten more, aligning with what was tested and measured. 

Option (B) involves measuring the slugs' weight after eating, which is not mentioned as being part of the experiment. Therefore, option (A) is more appropriate.

The image shows a desert landscape with sandy soil and sparse vegetation. The terrain includes sand dunes and some hardy plants, typical of desert environments, with mountains visible in the background. The scene signifies an arid climate, characteristic of deserts.
1435.solution: The Mojave Desert is known to have an arid climate with low rainfall. The image depicts sparse vegetation, suggesting the presence of several adapted plant species. Deserts typically have dry, thin soil and a variety of organisms adapted to the harsh conditions. Option A states the Mojave Desert has dry, thin soil and many types of organisms, which aligns with typical desert characteristics. Option B mentions a limited number of organisms, which is less characteristic of deserts that often host diverse adapted species. Therefore, Option A better describes the Mojave Desert ecosystem.

When Lisa and Kim finally landed, she breathed a sigh of relief.

Vague pronoun references can be corrected in one of two ways:

1439.question:
Which type of sentence is this?
An avid reader, Braden attends weekly book club meetings, and he finishes several novels every month.
1439.subject: language science
1439.skill: Is the sentence simple, compound, complex, or compound-complex?
1439.lecture:
A clause is a group of words that contains both a subject and a predicate.
An independent clause is a complete thought that can stand alone as a sentence. A dependent clause (or subordinate clause) is not a complete thought and cannot stand alone as a sentence.
the oranges on our tree are ripe
The clause can stand alone. It is independent.
after we pick up Kevin from work
The clause cannot stand alone. It is dependent.
A simple sentence is made up of a single independent clause.
Ben and I spent all day relaxing by the pool.
Some simple sentences have introductory phrases, but the introductory phrase is part of the predicate.
In the winter, Ben usually wears his heavy coat.
Ben usually wears his heavy coat in the winter.
A compound sentence is made up of two independent clauses joined by a coordinating conjunction such as and, but, or, or so.
We saw the flash of lightning, and seconds later we heard a rumble of thunder.
A complex sentence is made up of an independent clause and a dependent clause. The dependent clause in a complex sentence usually begins with a subordinating conjunction or relative pronoun. Subordinating conjunctions include after, although, as, because, before, if, since, unless, until, when, and while. Relative pronouns include that, which, who, whom, or whose.
If she ever gets the chance, Terri would love to visit the Egyptian pyramids.
During his trip to Italy, Tony visited the Trevi Fountain, which is in Rome.
A compound-complex sentence is made up of two or more independent clauses and one or more dependent clauses.
After Samantha left work, she stopped at the bank, and then she went to the gym.
Sometimes a dependent clause in a complex or compound-complex sentence can interrupt an independent clause.
Orcas that are kept in captivity often have bent dorsal fins.
1439.solution:
The sentence is compound. It is made up of two independent clauses joined by the coordinating conjunction and.
An avid reader, Braden attends weekly book club meetings, and he finishes several novels every month.

1441.question: Is Oxalis acetosella made up of one cell?
1441.hint:
This organism is Oxalis acetosella. It is a member of the plant kingdom.
Oxalis acetosella is commonly called wood sorrel. A wood sorrel plant has heart-shaped leaves and white flowers. Its flowers and leaves can fold up at night. Folding up helps protect the flowers and leaves from being eaten by insects.
1441.subject: natural science
1441.lecture:
In the past, scientists classified living organisms into two groups: plants and animals. Over the past 300 years, scientists have discovered many more types of organisms. Today, many scientists classify organisms into six broad groups, called kingdoms.
Organisms in each kingdom have specific traits. The table below shows some traits used to describe each kingdom.
 | Bacteria | Archaea | Protists | Fungi | Animals | Plants
How many cells do they have? | one | one | one or many | one or many | many | many
Do their cells have a nucleus? | no | no | yes | yes | yes | yes
Can their cells make food? | some species can | some species can | some species can | no | no | yes
1441.solution: Oxalis acetosella is a plant. Plants are made up of many cells.

1442.question: Using only these supplies, which question can Sean investigate with an experiment?
choices: Does white sandwich bread grow visible mold in fewer days if the bread is stored inside or outside the refrigerator?
Does white sandwich bread grow visible mold in fewer days if the bread is stored in a paper bag or in a plastic bag?
Does white or whole wheat sandwich bread grow visible mold in fewer days?
1442.hint:
Sean starts to make a sandwich, but he sees mold on the bread! He wonders what factors affect how mold grows on bread. So, he decides to design an experiment. He has the following supplies available:
two loaves of white sandwich bread
a small plastic bag
a large plastic bag
a refrigerator
1442.subject: natural science
1442.skill: Identify questions that can be investigated with a set of materials
1442.lecture:
Experiments can be designed to answer specific questions. When designing an experiment, you must identify the supplies that are necessary to answer your question. In order to do this, you need to figure out what will be tested and what will be measured during the experiment.
Imagine that you are wondering if plants grow to different heights when planted in different types of soil. How might you decide what supplies are necessary to conduct this experiment?
First, you need to identify the part of the experiment that will be tested, which is the independent variable. This is usually the part of the experiment that is different or changed. In this case, you would like to know how plants grow in different types of soil. So, you must have different types of soil available.
Next, you need to identify the part of the experiment that will be measured or observed, which is the dependent variable. In this experiment, you would like to know if some plants grow taller than others. So, you must be able to compare the plants' heights. To do this, you can observe which plants are taller by looking at them, or you can measure their exact heights with a meterstick.
So, if you have different types of soil and can observe or measure the heights of your plants, then you have the supplies you need to investigate your question with an experiment!

1443.question:
Is the following trait inherited or acquired?
Lola has naturally blond hair.
1443.hint: Hint: Some people dye their hair. But this does not change their natural hair color.
1443.subject: natural science
1443.lecture:
Organisms, including people, have both inherited and acquired traits. Inherited and acquired traits are gained in different ways.
Inherited traits are passed down through families. Children gain these traits from their parents. Inherited traits do not need to be learned.
Acquired traits are gained during a person's life. Some acquired traits, such as riding a bicycle, are gained by learning. Other acquired traits, such as scars, are caused by the environment. Children do not inherit their parents' acquired traits.
1443.solution: Humans do not choose their natural hair color. Instead, children get their natural hair color from their parents. So, Lola's hair color is an inherited trait.

1444.subject: language science
1444.skill: Recall the source of an allusion
1444.lecture:
An allusion is a brief mention of something or someone well known, often from mythology, history, or literature. An allusion lets you reference ideas from an entire story in just a few words.
"I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!" Lila remarked.
Here, Lila alludes to the fairy tale "Cinderella," in which Cinderella must leave the ball before the coach that brought her transforms into a pumpkin. The allusion shows that Lila must depart immediately.
1444.solution:
The source of the allusion Romeo is literature.
In William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet, Romeo is known for the eloquent declaration of love with which he woos Juliet.
The allusion Romeo means a man who is very romantic.

1446.question: What is the volume of a bathtub?
1446.subject: natural science
1446.lecture:
Measurements are written with both a number and a unit. The unit comes after the number. The unit shows what the number means.
Volume is a measurement of how much space something takes up.
There are many different units of volume. When you are using metric units, volume may be written in units of milliliters or liters.
There are 1,000 milliliters in 1 liter. So, 1 milliliter is much less than 1 liter.
A raindrop has a volume of about 20 milliliters, while a large soda bottle has a volume of 2 liters. The flask shown here measures volumes up to 500 milliliters.
1446.solution:
The better estimate for the volume of a bathtub is 375 liters.
375 milliliters is too little.

1449.question: Which sentence is more formal?
choices: On a date next week TBD, the library will close so that new computers can be installed.
The library will close for one day next week so that new computers can be installed.
1449.subject: language science
1449.lecture:
Formal writing is used for essays, business letters, and reports. The following types of informal language should be avoided in formal writing:
Type | Examples
slang | cool, awesome
idioms | knock your socks off
conversational language | gonna, kinda, yeah
abbreviated language | ASAP, FYI
overly simple or imprecise language | he got some stuff at the store
contractions | can't, won't
Contractions are not as informal as the other types, but they should be used sparingly in formal writing.
Compare the following sentences. The first is informal. The second is formal.
Informal: Yeah, ostriches can't fly, but they're awesome runners.
Formal: Though ostriches are flightless, they are remarkably adept runners.
1449.solution:
The second sentence is less formal. You can tell because it uses abbreviated language (TBD).
The first sentence does not use abbreviated language, so it is more formal.

1450.question: Think about the magnetic force between the magnets in each pair. Which of the following statements is true?
choices: The magnitude of the magnetic force is smaller in Pair 2.
The magnitude of the magnetic force is the same in both pairs.
The magnitude of the magnetic force is smaller in Pair 1.
1450.hint: The images below show two pairs of magnets. The magnets in different pairs do not affect each other. All the magnets shown are made of the same material.
1450.subject: natural science
1450.lecture:
To determine which statement about the magnetic force between pairs of magnets is accurate, I will analyze the distances between the magnets and relate the distance to the strength of the magnetic force. I will then compare the pairs based on these observations.

The image shows two pairs of magnets labeled Pair 1 and Pair 2. In Pair 1, two magnets are 1.05 cm apart, with "N" and "S" poles facing each other. In Pair 2, two magnets are 1.75 cm apart, also with "N" and "S" poles facing each other.
1450.solution: Magnetic force depends on the distance between the magnets; the closer the magnets, the stronger the magnetic force, and vice versa. In Pair 1, the magnets are 1.05 cm apart, while in Pair 2, they are 1.75 cm apart. Since Pair 1 has the smaller distance between the magnets, the magnetic force will be stronger in Pair 1 compared to Pair 2. Therefore, the magnitude of the magnetic force is smaller in Pair 2.

1451.question: Which solution has a higher concentration of pink particles?
choices: neither; their concentrations are the same
1451.hint: The diagram below is a model of two solutions. Each pink ball represents one particle of solute.
1451.subject: natural science
1451.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will analyze the image to determine the number of pink particles (solute) in each solution and relate them to the solvent's volume. This is crucial for calculating the concentration of each solution using the formula: concentration = particles of solute / volume of solvent. I will complete these steps to identify which solution has a higher concentration of pink particles.

The image depicts two Erlenmeyer flasks labeled as Solution A and Solution B. Both solutions contain a solvent volume of 50 mL. In Solution A, there are 10 pink particles, whereas Solution B contains 5 pink particles. The pink particles represent the solute in each solution.
1451.solution:
To find which solution has a higher concentration of pink particles, I will use the concentration formula: concentration = particles of solute / volume of solvent.

- For Solution A: 
  - Number of pink particles (solute) = 10 
  - Solvent volume = 50 mL 
  - Concentration = 10 particles / 50 mL = 0.2 particles/mL

- For Solution B:
  - Number of pink particles (solute) = 5 
  - Solvent volume = 50 mL 
  - Concentration = 5 particles / 50 mL = 0.1 particles/mL

Comparing the concentrations, Solution A has a higher concentration of pink particles than Solution B.

1452.question: Select the organism in the same species as the plains zebra.
1452.hint: This organism is a plains zebra. Its scientific name is Equus quagga.
1452.subject: natural science
1452.skill: Use scientific names to classify organisms
1452.lecture:
To identify the organism in the same species as the plains zebra, I will compare the scientific names provided in the options with the scientific name of the plains zebra, Equus quagga.

The image shows a plains zebra, characterized by its distinctive black and white striped coat, standing in a grassland environment.
1452.solution: The scientific name of the plains zebra is Equus quagga. To determine which option represents an organism of the same species, I need to find the option with the exact scientific name, Equus quagga. Option (B) is Equus quagga, which matches the species name of the plains zebra. Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer as it is the same species.

1453.question: Which solution has a higher concentration of blue particles?
choices: neither; their concentrations are the same
1453.hint: The diagram below is a model of two solutions. Each blue ball represents one particle of solute.
1453.subject: natural science
1453.lecture:
To determine which solution has a higher concentration, I'll calculate the ratio of solute particles to solvent volume for both solutions. I will analyze the image to count the particles and confirm the solvent volume, then compute the concentration and compare them.

The image shows two solutions, A and B, each containing blue particles within a solvent. The solvent volume is indicated as 45 mL for both solutions. In Solution A, there are 15 blue particles, and in Solution B, there are also 15 blue particles.
1453.solution:
The concentration of a solution is calculated by dividing the number of solute particles by the volume of the solvent. Both Solution A and Solution B have 15 blue particles and a solvent volume of 45 mL. Therefore, the concentration for both solutions is:
\[ \text{Concentration} = \frac{\text{Number of particles}}{\text{Solvent volume}} = \frac{15}{45} = \frac{1}{3} \text{ particles/mL} \]
Thus, the concentrations for Solution A and Solution B are equal, as both have the same ratio of solute particles to solvent volume.

1454.question: Which type of relationship is formed when a bristle worm lives on a white sea urchin?
1454.hint:
Read the passage. Then answer the question.

White sea urchins live in tropical oceans. Sea urchins are covered with hard, sharp spines. These spear-like spines protect the sea urchin from predators, such as fish. Sometimes a small worm, called a bristle worm, also uses the spines for protection.
The worm lives on the sea urchin, between the spines. To attack a worm on the sea urchin's body, a fish would have to get past the spines. When the worm lives on the sea urchin, the worm does not change the sea urchin's ability to survive.
Figure: a white sea urchin in the ocean.
1454.subject: natural science
1454.lecture:
When two organisms of different species interact in a way that affects one or both organisms, they form a symbiotic relationship. The word symbiosis comes from a Greek word that means living together. Scientists define types of symbiotic relationships based on how each organism is affected.
This table lists three common types of symbiotic relationships. It shows how each organism is affected in each type of symbiotic relationship.
Type of symbiotic relationship | Organism of one species... | Organism of the other species...
Commensal | benefits | is not significantly affected
Mutualistic | benefits | benefits
Parasitic | benefits | is harmed (but not usually killed)
1454.solution:
When a bristle worm lives on a white sea urchin, the worm is protected from predators by the sea urchin's sharp spines. So, the worm benefits from its relationship with the sea urchin.
The sea urchin's ability to survive does not change when a worm lives on it. So, the sea urchin is not significantly affected by its relationship with the worm.
Since the worm benefits and the sea urchin is not significantly affected, a commensal relationship is formed when a bristle worm lives on a white sea urchin.

1455.question:
Which tense does the sentence use?
Judith will sweep the sidewalk in front of her store.
1455.subject: language science
1455.skill: Is the sentence in the past, present, or future tense?
1455.lecture:
Present tense verbs tell you about something that is happening now.
Most present-tense verbs are regular. They have no ending, or they end in -s or -es.
Two verbs are irregular in the present tense, to be and to have. You must remember their forms.
Past tense verbs tell you about something that has already happened.
Most past-tense verbs are regular. They end in -ed.
Some verbs are irregular in the past tense. You must remember their past-tense forms.
Future tense verbs tell you about something that is going to happen.
All future-tense verbs use the word will.
Present | Past | Future
walk, walks | walked | will walk
go, goes | went | will go
1455.solution: The sentence is in future tense. You can tell because it uses will before the main verb, sweep. The verb tells you about something that is going to happen.

1456.question: Select the organism in the same genus as the bighorn sheep.
1456.hint: This organism is a bighorn sheep. Its scientific name is Ovis canadensis.
1456.subject: natural science
1456.skill: Use scientific names to classify organisms
1456.lecture:
I will identify the organism in the same genus as the bighorn sheep by examining their scientific names. The first word of the scientific name indicates the genus. I will compare this with the options provided to choose the correct organism.

The image shows a bighorn sheep standing on a rocky surface. The sheep is characterized by its large, curved horns and robust body.
1456.solution:
The bighorn sheep's scientific name is Ovis canadensis. The question requires identifying the organism from the options that share the same genus, Ovis. The options given are Macropus agilis, Hystrix cristata, and Ovis dalli. 

- Macropus agilis has the genus Macropus, so it is not in the same genus.
- Hystrix cristata has the genus Hystrix, so it is not in the same genus.
- Ovis dalli has the genus Ovis, which matches the genus of the bighorn sheep.

Therefore, Ovis dalli is in the same genus as the bighorn sheep.

1457.question: Think about the magnetic force between the magnets in each pair. Which of the following statements is true?
choices: The magnitude of the magnetic force is smaller in Pair 1.
The magnitude of the magnetic force is the same in both pairs.
The magnitude of the magnetic force is smaller in Pair 2.
1457.hint: The images below show two pairs of magnets. The magnets in different pairs do not affect each other. All the magnets shown are made of the same material, but some of them are different sizes.
1457.subject: natural science
1457.lecture:
Magnets can pull or push on each other without touching. When magnets attract, they pull together. When magnets repel, they push apart. These pulls and pushes between magnets are called magnetic forces.
The strength of a force is called its magnitude. The greater the magnitude of the magnetic force between two magnets, the more strongly the magnets attract or repel each other.
You can change the magnitude of a magnetic force between two magnets by using magnets of different sizes. The magnitude of the magnetic force is smaller when the magnets are smaller.
1457.solution:
Magnet sizes affect the magnitude of the magnetic force. Imagine magnets that are the same shape and made of the same material. The smaller the magnets, the smaller the magnitude of the magnetic force between them.
Magnet A is the same size in both pairs. But Magnet B is smaller in Pair 2 than in Pair 1. So, the magnitude of the magnetic force is smaller in Pair 2 than in Pair 1.

1458.question: Which property do these four objects have in common?
1458.subject: natural science
1458.lecture:
I will analyze the image to determine which property all four objects share. I'll examine each object for the properties outlined in the options: flexible, smooth, and opaque.

The image contains four objects: a baseball bat, a ceramic mug labeled "XL," a sheet of paper, and a water pitcher. The visual focus is on identifying common properties of these objects.
1458.solution:
To determine the shared property among the objects, we assess each one's characteristics based on the given properties:

- **Baseball bat**: Typically smooth and opaque; not flexible.
- **Ceramic mug**: Smooth, opaque, and not flexible.
- **Paper**: Flexible and generally smooth, not opaque.
- **Water pitcher**: Likely smooth, not flexible, and might be translucent but not opaque.

Analyzing the options:
- **Flexible**: Only the paper fits this; others don't.
- **Smooth**: All objects, including the baseball bat, ceramic mug, paper, and pitcher, can be described as smooth.
- **Opaque**: The baseball bat and mug are opaque, but not the paper and pitcher.

Therefore, smooth is the only property that applies to all four objects.

1459.question:
Is this a sentence fragment?
Smoke from the cabin visible for miles up and down the coast.
1459.subject: language science
1459.lecture:
A sentence is a group of words that expresses a complete thought.
The band I'm in has been rehearsing daily because we have a concert in two weeks.
A sentence fragment is a group of words that does not express a complete thought.
Rehearsing daily because we have a concert in two weeks.
This fragment is missing a subject. It doesn't tell who is rehearsing.
The band I'm in.
This fragment is missing a verb. It doesn't tell what the band I'm in is doing.
Because we have a concert in two weeks.
This fragment is missing an independent clause. It doesn't tell what happened because of the concert.
1459.solution:
This is a sentence fragment. It does not express a complete thought.
Smoke from the cabin visible for miles up and down the coast.
Here is one way to fix the sentence fragment:
Smoke from the cabin is visible for miles up and down the coast.

1460.question: Which country is highlighted?
1460.subject: social science

1460.lecture:
To determine the highlighted country, I will examine the geographical location and features of the area marked in the image. Using this information, I will identify the country from the given options.

The image shows a map of the Caribbean region. It highlights a small group of islands located towards the southeast, marked by a green square.
1460.solution: The highlighted area in the map is located in the eastern Caribbean, showing a group of islands. From the given options, these islands align with Saint Vincent and the Grenadines due to their position and size in the Caribbean region. Barbados is located to the east, Haiti is much larger and to the northwest, and Grenada is situated south of the highlighted area.

1461.question: What is the capital of Michigan?
1461.subject: social science
1461.skill: Identify state capitals of the Midwest
1461.lecture:
I will analyze the image to identify Michigan and use the provided options to determine its capital, following each step carefully.

The image shows a map of the United States with Michigan highlighted in a darker shade.
