Historically and geographically, Lansing is known as the capital of Michigan. Therefore, based on this information, I can derive the correct answer.

1462.question: Using only these supplies, which question can Clarence investigate with an experiment?
choices: Do the squirrels eat walnuts from large feeders more often than from small feeders?
Do the squirrels select sunflower seeds or walnuts more often?
Which type of tree do the squirrels feed from most often?
1462.hint:
Clarence enjoys feeding the squirrels in his backyard. He notices that they spend a lot of time collecting seeds and nuts. He wonders about what factors affect which foods squirrels choose to collect. So, he decides to design an experiment. He has the following supplies available:
two identical squirrel feeders
a bag of sunflower seeds
a bag of walnuts
a tree to hang the feeders from
1462.subject: natural science
1462.skill: Identify questions that can be investigated with a set of materials
1462.lecture:
Experiments can be designed to answer specific questions. When designing an experiment, you must identify the supplies that are necessary to answer your question. In order to do this, you need to figure out what will be tested and what will be measured during the experiment.
Imagine that you are wondering if plants grow to different heights when planted in different types of soil. How might you decide what supplies are necessary to conduct this experiment?
First, you need to identify the part of the experiment that will be tested, which is the independent variable. This is usually the part of the experiment that is different or changed. In this case, you would like to know how plants grow in different types of soil. So, you must have different types of soil available.
Next, you need to identify the part of the experiment that will be measured or observed, which is the dependent variable. In this experiment, you would like to know if some plants grow taller than others. So, you must be able to compare the plants' heights. To do this, you can observe which plants are taller by looking at them, or you can measure their exact heights with a meterstick.
So, if you have different types of soil and can observe or measure the heights of your plants, then you have the supplies you need to investigate your question with an experiment!

1463.question: Two baked potatoes have the same temperature but different masses. Which potato has more thermal energy?
choices: the baked potato with more mass
the baked potato with less mass
1463.hint: The objects are made of the same type of matter.
1463.subject: natural science
1463.skill: How are temperature and mass related to thermal energy?
1463.lecture:
Matter is made of tiny particles called atoms. Atoms are always moving.
The energy of moving atoms is called thermal energy. The total amount of thermal energy in matter depends on three things: the type of matter, the amount of matter, and how fast the atoms are moving.
Temperature measures how hot or cold matter is. If the atoms in matter move faster, the temperature goes up. The matter now has both more thermal energy and a higher temperature.
What happens if the amount of matter changes? A 2-kilogram brick at 70°F has twice as much thermal energy as a 1-kilogram brick at 70°F. The two bricks have the same temperature, but the larger brick has twice as many atoms. So, it has twice as much thermal energy.
1463.solution: The two baked potatoes have the same temperature and are made of the same type of matter. So, the baked potato with more mass has more thermal energy.

1464.question:
Which word would you find on a dictionary page with the following guide words?
pillar - promise
1464.subject: language science
1464.lecture:
Guide words appear on each page of a dictionary. They tell you the first word and last word on the page. The other words on the page come between the guide words in alphabetical order.
To put words in alphabetical order, put them in order by their first letters. If the first letters are the same, look at the second letters. If the second letters are the same, look at the third letters, and so on.
If one word is shorter, and there are no more letters to compare, then the shorter word comes first in alphabetical order.
1464.solution:
To determine which word would be found on a dictionary page between the guide words pillar and promise, we need to compare the letters of the potential words with the respective letters of the guide words.
The first letter of palm is p, which matches the first letter of the guide words. Moving on to the second letter, a is before i (the second letter of pillar). Therefore, the word palm would be before and NOT be found on a dictionary page between the guide words pillar and promise.
The first letter of potato is p, which matches the first letter of the guide words. Moving on to the second letter, o is after i (the second letter of pillar) and before r (the second letter of promise). Therefore, the word potato would be found on a dictionary page between the guide words pillar and promise.
Hence, the correct answer is potato.

1465.question: Which of the following could Pablo's test show?
choices: the amount of bacteria in the water before it was filtered
whether an inexpensive filter would become clogged more often
1465.hint:
People can use the engineering-design process to develop solutions to problems. One step in the process is testing if a potential solution meets the requirements of the design.
The passage below describes how the engineering-design process was used to test a solution to a problem. Read the passage. Then answer the question below.

Pablo was . At the plant, an expensive filter was used to remove disease-causing bacteria from the water. But over time, the filter would become clogged with bacteria. If the filter became clogged, the water would not move through quickly enough. Pablo had to decide when the filter was too clogged and needed to be replaced. So, during his inspection, Pablo checked the filter by measuring how quickly water moved through it.
Figure: an engineer at a water treatment plant.
1465.subject: natural science
1465.lecture:
To answer the question, I'll analyze the image and provided context to identify what aspect of the water filter system Pablo tested. I'll focus on the given options (A, B, C) to determine which one aligns with the evidence from the image and text.

The image shows an engineer at a water treatment plant inspecting equipment. The engineer is closely examining a component of the system, which could be related to water flow or filtration, while wearing appropriate safety gear.
1465.solution: The context describes Pablo's task of assessing when a water filter becomes too clogged with bacteria, affecting flow rate. His procedure involves measuring the water's flow through the filter during inspections. The key measurement here is the speed of water movement, which directly indicates whether the filter is clogged. This aligns with option B: "whether the filter was clogged," which focuses on determining if the filter's effectiveness is compromised by blockage. Options A and C don't directly relate to what Pablo is testing, as his measurements target flow rate, not bacteria amount or frequency of clogs in different filters.

1466.question: Select the organism in the same species as the bighorn sheep.
1466.hint: This organism is a bighorn sheep. Its scientific name is Ovis canadensis.
1466.subject: natural science
1466.skill: Use scientific names to classify organisms
1466.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will analyze the scientific name of the bighorn sheep and compare it with the given options. The correct answer will be the option with the identical scientific name.

The image depicts a bighorn sheep standing on a rocky hillside, identifiable by its large, curved horns and stocky build.
1466.solution:
The scientific name of the bighorn sheep is Ovis canadensis. According to scientific naming conventions, organisms belonging to the same species have the exact same two-part scientific name. I will compare this name with each option: 

- Option A: Ovis canadensis. This matches the scientific name of the bighorn sheep.
- Option B: Alouatta palliata. This does not match.
- Option C: Alouatta caraya. This also does not match.

Since Ovis canadensis matches the scientific name of the bighorn sheep, it is in the same species.

1467.question: Which country is highlighted?
1467.subject: social science
1467.skill: Identify and select countries of Oceania
1467.lecture:
To solve the problem, I'll analyze the image, identify the highlighted area, and cross-reference it with the options given to find the correct country.

The image shows a map of the Oceania region, including parts of Australia and nearby islands. A specific area is highlighted with a green border in the southeastern part of the map.
1467.solution: The highlighted area is situated in the South Pacific, east of Australia and north of New Zealand. It corresponds to a cluster of islands commonly associated with Fiji. The location and extent in the map best match Fiji's geographical placement in the options provided.

1468.question:
What does the verbal irony in this text suggest?
"That fits you well," Tamir remarked after Kinsley's cap fell over her eyes for the tenth time.
choices: The cap was a good fit.
1468.subject: language science
1468.lecture:
Figures of speech are words or phrases that use language in a nonliteral or unusual way. They can make writing more expressive.
Verbal irony involves saying one thing but implying something very different. People often use verbal irony when they are being sarcastic.
Olivia seems thrilled that her car keeps breaking down.
Each breakdown is as enjoyable as a punch to the face.
1468.solution:
The text uses verbal irony, which involves saying one thing but implying something very different.
Fits you well ironically suggests that the cap was too big. The cap was falling over Kinsley's eyes, so it didn't fit her well at all.

1469.question: How long is a hammer?
1469.subject: natural science
1469.lecture:
Measurements are written with both a number and a unit. The unit comes after the number. The unit shows what the number means.
Imagine being told that a pencil is 16 long. You might be thinking, 16 what? Is the pencil 16 centimeters long? 16 meters? 16 kilometers?
The number 16 on its own does not give you much information about the length of the pencil. That is because the units are missing.
Now look at the drawing of the pencil and the ruler. The ruler shows that the units are centimeters. So, the length of the pencil is 16 centimeters.
There are 100 centimeters in 1 meter. So, 1 centimeter is much shorter than 1 meter.
There are 1,000 meters in 1 kilometer. So, 1 meter is much shorter than 1 kilometer.
1469.solution:
The better estimate for the length of a hammer is 25 centimeters.
25 meters is too long.

1470.question: Which animal is also adapted to be camouflaged in the snow?
1470.hint:
Polar bears live in and around the cold Arctic Ocean. The  is adapted to be camouflaged in the snow.
Figure: polar bear.
1470.subject: natural science
1470.skill: Animal adaptations: skins and body coverings
1470.lecture:
To determine which animal is adapted to be camouflaged in the snow, I'll analyze the image and compare the adaptations of two options. I'll focus on the animal's coloration as it relates to camouflage in snowy environments.

The image depicts a polar bear, which is a large animal with white fur. This white fur helps the polar bear blend into its snowy surroundings, providing camouflage.
1470.solution: To identify the animal adapted to snow camouflage, I need to compare the polar bear's adaptation with the options provided. The polar bear's white fur allows it to blend with the snow. Option (A), the Arctic fox, also has white fur during the winter, indicating it shares this adaptation. Option (B), the screech owl, has gray and brown feathers, which are not suited for snowy camouflage. Therefore, the Arctic fox has a similar camouflage adaptation to the polar bear.

1471.question: Which animal's feet are also adapted for grabbing prey?
1471.hint:
Golden eagles eat fish, mammals, and other birds. The 's feet are adapted to grab prey.
Figure: golden eagle.
1471.subject: natural science
1471.lecture:
I will identify which animal's feet are adapted for grabbing prey by examining relevant details in the image and comparing these features with the options provided.

The image shows a golden eagle with its wings spread and talons extended. The eagle has long toes with sharp claws, indicating an adaptation for grabbing and holding prey.
1471.solution: The image depicts a golden eagle with prominent talons and long toes, adaptations for capturing and holding prey effectively. To determine which option shares a similar adaptation, we compare the characteristics of both animals: The African crowned eagle is known for its long toes and sharp claws, similar to the golden eagle, used for grasping prey. In contrast, the Malayan tapir has large, heavy feet, adapted for movement rather than grabbing prey. Thus, the African crowned eagle possesses feet adapted for grabbing prey.

1472.question: What is the mass of a trumpet?
1472.subject: natural science
1472.lecture:
Measurements are written with both a number and a unit. The unit comes after the number. The unit shows what the number means.
Mass is a measurement of how much matter something contains.
There are many different units of mass. When you are using metric units, mass may be written with units of grams or kilograms.
There are 1,000 grams in 1 kilogram. So, 1 gram is much less than 1 kilogram.
A paper clip has a mass of about 1 gram, while a textbook has a mass of about 1 kilogram.
1472.solution:
The better estimate for the mass of a trumpet is 1 kilogram.
1 gram is too light.

1473.question: Which of the following contains a vague pronoun reference?
choices: According to Rebecca, Willie Mays hit 660 career home runs, although Joe DiMaggio had a higher batting average. She said that he is her favorite player.
According to Rebecca, Willie Mays hit 660 career home runs, although Joe DiMaggio had a higher batting average. She said that Mays is her favorite player.
1473.subject: language science
1473.lecture:
When writing, make sure to avoid vague pronoun references. A vague pronoun reference occurs when a pronoun could refer to more than one possible antecedent.
When Lisa and Kim finally landed, she breathed a sigh of relief.
The pronoun she could refer to either Lisa or Kim, so the meaning of the sentence is unclear.
Vague pronoun references can be corrected in one of two ways:
1. Replace the pronoun with its correct antecedent:
When Lisa and Kim finally landed, Lisa breathed a sigh of relief.
2. Rewrite the sentence:
Lisa breathed a sigh of relief when she and Kim finally landed.
A vague pronoun reference also occurs when they, them, their, theirs, it, or its is used without its antecedent.
They say that this nail polish dries in less than five minutes.
The pronoun they is used without its antecedent, so the meaning of the sentence is unclear.
This problem can be fixed by replacing the pronoun with its missing antecedent.
The advertisements say that this nail polish dries in less than five minutes.
1473.solution:
The second answer choice contains a vague pronoun reference. The pronoun he could refer to Joe Di Maggio or Willie Mays.
The first answer choice shows a possible correction for the vague pronoun reference. He has been replaced with Mays.
According to Rebecca, Willie Mays hit 660 career home runs, although Joe DiMaggio had a higher batting average. She said that Mays is her favorite player.

1474.question: Think about the magnetic force between the magnets in each pair. Which of the following statements is true?
choices: The magnitude of the magnetic force is smaller in Pair 1.
The magnitude of the magnetic force is smaller in Pair 2.
The magnitude of the magnetic force is the same in both pairs.
1474.hint: The images below show two pairs of magnets. The magnets in different pairs do not affect each other. All the magnets shown are made of the same material, but some of them are different sizes and shapes.
1474.subject: natural science
1474.lecture:
To solve this problem, I'll examine the image to understand the magnets' sizes and configurations in each pair. I'll then analyze how these factors affect the magnetic forces between the magnets in each pair, ultimately identifying which pair experiences a smaller magnetic force.

The image displays two pairs of magnets labeled Pair 1 and Pair 2. Each pair contains two circular magnets divided into sections labeled "N" (north) and "S" (south). Pair 1 consists of a smaller inner set and a larger outer ring, with a labeled distance of 39.1 mm between them. Pair 2 features a larger inner magnet and a larger outer ring, also with a labeled distance of 39.1 mm.
1474.solution: The magnetic force between two magnets depends on their sizes, shapes, materials, and distances between them. Since all magnets in the image are made of the same material and separated by the same distance (39.1 mm), the key factor affecting the magnitude of the magnetic force is their size. In Pair 1, one magnet is significantly smaller than the corresponding magnet in Pair 2. Since smaller magnets exert weaker magnetic forces than larger ones, the magnitude of the magnetic force in Pair 1 will be smaller compared to Pair 2. Thus, because the magnets in Pair 2 are larger, they produce a stronger magnetic force.

1475.question: Which country is highlighted?
1475.subject: social science
1475.skill: Identify and select countries of the Caribbean
1475.lecture:
To identify the highlighted country, I will analyze the image focusing on the area marked in dark green and compare it with the provided options to match it with the correct country.

The image shows a map of the Caribbean region with a focus on a specific island. Part of this island is highlighted in dark green, while surrounding islands are shaded in a lighter green. The highlighted area is on the eastern part of the island named Hispaniola.
1475.solution: The map features the island of Hispaniola, which is divided into two countries. The eastern portion of the island, marked in dark green, corresponds to the Dominican Republic, while the western part serves as Haiti. Therefore, the portion highlighted in the map indicates the country of the Dominican Republic.

1476.question: Is a fork a solid, a liquid, or a gas?
1476.subject: natural science
1476.skill: Classify matter as solid, liquid, or gas
1476.lecture:
To determine whether a fork is a solid, liquid, or gas, I will analyze the characteristics of these states of matter and compare them with the properties of a fork depicted in the image.

The image shows a metal fork with four tines. It appears shiny and reflective, indicating that it is made of a solid material, likely metal.
1476.solution: A solid has a definite volume and shape. A fork, made of metal, maintains its size and shape unless significant force is applied. It does not flow and retains its structure. Liquids, on the other hand, have a definite volume but take the shape of their container, which does not apply to the fork. Gases lack both definite shape and volume. Thus, the fork's characteristics align with those of a solid.

1477.question: Select the one substance that is not a rock.
choices: Granodiorite is not made by living things. It is a solid.
A brick is made in a factory. It is not a pure substance.
Limestone is formed in nature. It is not a pure substance.
1477.subject: natural science
1477.lecture:
Rocks are made of minerals. Here are some properties of rocks:
They are solid.
They are formed in nature.
They are not made by living things.
They are not pure substances.
1477.solution:
Compare the properties of each substance to the properties of rocks. Select the substance whose properties do not match those of rocks.
Granodiorite is a rock.
A brick is made in a factory. But all rocks are formed in nature.
So, a brick is not a rock.
Limestone is a rock.

1478.question: What is the expected ratio of offspring with green peas to offspring with yellow peas? Choose the most likely ratio.
1478.hint:
In a group of pea plants, some individuals have yellow peas and others have green peas. In this group, the gene for the pea color trait has two alleles. The allele for green peas (e) is recessive to the allele for yellow peas (E).
This Punnett square shows a cross between two pea plants.This Punnett square is Ee

Ee

ee

ee
1478.subject: natural science
1478.skill: Use Punnett squares to calculate ratios of offspring types
1478.lecture:
I will analyze the provided Punnett square to determine the expected ratio of offspring with green peas to those with yellow peas. By identifying the genotype for each phenotype and counting the relevant boxes on the Punnett square, I will reach the final answer.

The image displays a Punnett square indicating a genetic cross between two pea plants. It consists of four boxes that represent potential offspring genotypes: Ee, Ee, ee, and ee. The 'E' allele is dominant (yellow peas), and the 'e' allele is recessive (green peas).
1478.solution: To determine the phenotype, I need to look at the genotype of each box. The dominant allele 'E' results in yellow peas, and the recessive allele 'e' results in green peas. For offspring to express green peas, they must have the genotype 'ee'. The Punnett square shows two boxes with the genotype 'ee', meaning two offspring with green peas. The other two boxes show the genotype 'Ee', which results in yellow peas. Therefore, the expected ratio of offspring with green peas to offspring with yellow peas is 2:2.

1479.question: Assume all other forces on the dresser are balanced. Which statement describes the forces on the dresser?
choices: The forces are unbalanced, so there is a net force on the dresser.
The forces are balanced, so there is no net force on the dresser.
1479.hint: Sophie is sliding a heavy dresser across the carpeted floor of her apartment. She is pushing the dresser forward with a force of 350N. The carpet is pushing the dresser backward with a force of 380N.
1479.subject: natural science
1479.lecture:
A force is a push or a pull that acts on an object. Every force has a direction and a magnitude, or strength. If two forces act on an object in opposite directions, the forces are called opposing forces.
When opposing forces have the same magnitude, they are balanced. If all the forces on an object are balanced, there is no net force on the object.
When opposing forces have different magnitudes, the forces are unbalanced. If any forces on an object are unbalanced, there is a net force on the object.
1479.solution:
To determine if there is a net force on the dresser, look at the forces:
Sophie is pushing the dresser forward with a force of 350 N.
The carpet is pushing the dresser backward with a force of 380 N.
The forces are in opposite directions, and the forces have different magnitudes: 350 N and 380 N. This means that the forces are unbalanced, so there is a net force on the dresser.

1480.question: Does this passage describe the weather or the climate?
1480.hint:
Figure: Yemen.
Yemen, a country in the Middle East, is located in the desert. It was humid in the southern part of the country on November 30 last year.
Hint: Weather is what the atmosphere is like at a certain place and time. Climate is the pattern of weather in a certain place.
1480.subject: natural science
1480.skill: Weather and climate around the world
1480.lecture:
To determine whether the passage describes weather or climate, I will assess the details regarding time and location in the passage. I will analyze the specific date mentioned to decide if it is a description of weather (specific time and place) or climate (general pattern over time).

The image depicts traditional Yemeni architecture under a clear sky, possibly indicating a typical dry desert environment that Yemen is known for, given its geographical location in the Middle East.
1480.solution: The passage states that it was humid in the southern part of Yemen on November 30 last year. The mention of a specific date ("November 30 last year") and a specific characteristic of the atmosphere ("humid") at a particular place suggests a temporary atmospheric condition rather than a long-term pattern. Therefore, this description aligns with the definition of weather, which refers to the atmospheric conditions at a specific time and location.

1481.question:
What is the source of the allusion in the sentence below?
"Mary is such a Pollyanna!" Fred announced with a sigh.
1481.subject: language science
1481.skill: Recall the source of an allusion
1481.lecture:
An allusion is a brief mention of something or someone well known, often from mythology, history, or literature. An allusion lets you reference ideas from an entire story in just a few words.
"I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!" Lila remarked.
Here, Lila alludes to the fairy tale "Cinderella," in which Cinderella must leave the ball before the coach that brought her transforms into a pumpkin. The allusion shows that Lila must depart immediately.
1481.solution:
The source of the allusion Pollyanna is literature.
The character Pollyanna, from Eleanor Porter's children's book, is a young girl who finds good in everything and everyone.
The allusion Pollyanna means an overly optimistic person.

1482.question: What is the capital of New Mexico?
1482.subject: social science
1482.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will first observe the image to determine the relevant state highlighted within the United States map. Next, I will identify which state it represents, and from there, determine its capital by analyzing and matching with the given options.

The image shows a map of the United States with all states colored light green, except for one state, which is colored a darker green. This darker green state is located in the southwestern region of the U.S.
1482.solution: The map highlights the state of New Mexico in a darker green shade. To find the capital of New Mexico, I consider the options provided: (A) Cambridge, (B) Salem, (C) Santa Fe, and (D) Albuquerque. By recognizing that Santa Fe is the capital of New Mexico, the correct option that matches is (C) Santa Fe.

1483.question: Which statement describes the Mount Rainier National Park ecosystem?
choices: It has long, cold winters and short, cool summers.
It has soil that is rich in nutrients.
1483.hint:
Figure: Mount Rainier National Park.
Mount Rainier National Park is a taiga ecosystem in Washington State. The park is named after a volcano called Mount Rainier, which is covered in glaciers.
1483.subject: natural science
1483.lecture:
To determine which statement accurately describes the Mount Rainier National Park ecosystem, I will analyze the image and context provided, and then compare this information with the options given to identify the correct ecological description.

The image shows a landscape of Mount Rainier National Park, depicting a mountainous terrain with dense evergreen forests. The sunlight illuminates the trees, suggesting a diverse environment with substantial vegetation.
1483.solution: Mount Rainier National Park is characterized as a taiga ecosystem. Taiga ecosystems are known for specific features, including long, cold winters and short, cool summers, as well as the presence of many evergreen trees. The description of a taiga ecosystem does not align with rich nutrient soil or environments dominated by small plants, which are typical of other ecosystems. Given that the image and context emphasize the presence of evergreen trees and mountainous terrain, the conditions fit the description of long, cold winters and short, cool summers better than the other options.

1484.question:
Would you find the word excite on a dictionary page with the following guide words?
engine - essay
1484.subject: language science
1484.lecture:
Guide words appear on each page of a dictionary. They tell you the first word and last word on the page. The other words on the page come between the guide words in alphabetical order.
To put words in alphabetical order, put them in order by their first letters. If the first letters are the same, look at the second letters. If the second letters are the same, look at the third letters, and so on.
If one word is shorter, and there are no more letters to compare, then the shorter word comes first in alphabetical order.
1484.solution:
To determine if the word excite would be found on a dictionary page between the guide words engine and essay, we need to compare the letters of excite with the respective letters of the guide words.
The first letter of excite is e, which matches the first letter of both guide words. Moving on to the second letter, x is after n (the second letter of engine) but after s (the second letter of essay).
Therefore, the word excite would be after and NOT be found on a dictionary page between the guide words engine and essay. The correct answer is no.

1485.question:
Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
No one in your family surfs? But I thought you said you lived in California before this.
choices: false causation: the assumption that because two things happened together, one caused the other
hasty generalization: a very broad claim based on very little evidence
1485.subject: language science
1485.lecture:
A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand, it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.
A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together, one caused the other
false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against
1485.solution: The text argues that a person from California must have a surfer in his or her family. However, even though some people in California surf, that doesn't necessarily mean that every family has a surfer. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a hasty generalization.

1486.question: Select the fish below.
1486.hint:
Fish live underwater. They have fins, not limbs.
Fish are cold-blooded. The body temperature of cold-blooded animals depends on their environment.
A hammerhead shark is an example of a fish.
1486.subject: natural science
1486.skill: Identify mammals, birds, fish, reptiles, and amphibians
1486.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will identify which of the options is classified as a fish by examining the traits associated with each option. I will focus on identifying the animal that lives underwater and has fins as described.

The image depicts a hammerhead shark, an example of a fish, swimming underwater. This highlights the characteristics of fish, such as living underwater and having fins.
1486.solution:
Based on animal classification, I need to identify which option is a fish. A fish is defined by living underwater and having fins. By analyzing each option: 
- A cane toad is an amphibian and doesn’t fit the fish characteristics.
- A salmon lives underwater and has fins, making it a fish.
- A water buffalo is a mammal and does not fit fish characteristics.
- A harbor seal is a mammal, not a fish, despite having flippers for swimming.
Given these classifications, the option matching the fish traits is salmon.

1487.question: Compare the average kinetic energies of the particles in each sample. Which sample has the higher temperature?
choices: neither; the samples have the same temperature
1487.hint: The diagrams below show two pure samples of gas in identical closed, rigid containers. Each colored ball represents one gas particle. Both samples have the same number of particles.
1487.subject: natural science
1487.skill: Identify how particle motion affects temperature and pressure
1487.lecture:
The temperature of a substance depends on the average kinetic energy of the particles in the substance. The higher the average kinetic energy of the particles, the higher the temperature of the substance.
The kinetic energy of a particle is determined by its mass and speed. For a pure substance, the greater the mass of each particle in the substance and the higher the average speed of the particles, the higher their average kinetic energy.
1487.solution:
Each particle in sample B has more mass than each particle in sample A. The particles in sample B also have a higher average speed than the particles in sample A. So, the particles in sample B have a higher average kinetic energy than the particles in sample A.
Because the particles in sample B have the higher average kinetic energy, sample B must have the higher temperature.

1488.question: Look at the models of molecules below. Select the elementary substance.
1488.subject: natural science
1488.skill: Identify elementary substances and compounds using models
1488.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will identify which molecule represents an elementary substance based on the given molecular structures and their compositions. I will describe the image's relevant details and use logical reasoning to determine the elementary substance from the options provided.

The image shows three molecular structures: chlorine, silane, and propane. In the chlorine model, there are two identical green balls connected, representing two chlorine atoms. The silane model features one beige ball (silicon) surrounded by four white balls (hydrogen). In the propane model, three black balls (carbon) are interconnected and surrounded by white balls (hydrogen). A legend identifies the colors: white for hydrogen (H), black for carbon (C), beige for silicon (Si), and green for chlorine (Cl).
1488.solution:
An elementary substance consists of only one chemical element. Examining the models: 
- Chlorine shows two identical atoms (green balls), both chlorine, indicating it comprises only one type of element. 
- Silane contains one silicon and four hydrogen atoms, meaning it is composed of multiple elements.
- Propane consists of carbon and hydrogen atoms, which means it is also a compound. 
Since an elementary substance must consist of only one element, chlorine is the only molecule that fits this criterion.

1489.question: Which month has the lowest average precipitation in London?
1489.hint: Use the graph to answer the question below.
1489.subject: natural science
1489.skill: Use climate data to make predictions
1489.lecture:
Scientists record climate data from places around the world. Precipitation, or rain and snow, is one type of climate data. Scientists collect data over many years. They can use this data to calculate the average precipitation for each month. The average precipitation can be used to describe the climate of a location.
A bar graph can be used to show the average amount of precipitation each month. Months with taller bars have more precipitation on average.
1489.solution:
To describe the average precipitation trends in London, look at the graph.
Choice "May" is incorrect.
Choice "Jul" is incorrect.
Choice "Nov" is incorrect.
July has an average monthly precipitation of about 45 millimeters. This is lower than in any other month. So, July has the lowest average precipitation.

1490.question: What is the capital of Nebraska?
1490.subject: social science
1490.skill: Identify state capitals of the Midwest
1490.solution: Lincoln is the capital of Nebraska.

1491.question: What information supports the conclusion that Ryan acquired this trait?
choices: Ryan knits sweaters using cotton, wool, and other types of yarn.
Ryan learned how to knit in an after school program.
1491.hint:
Read the description of a trait.
Ryan knows how to knit sweaters.
1491.subject: natural science
1491.skill: Inherited and acquired traits: use evidence to support a statement
1491.lecture:
Organisms, including people, have both inherited and acquired traits. Inherited and acquired traits are gained in different ways.
Inherited traits are passed down through families. Children gain these traits from their parents. Inherited traits do not need to be learned.
Acquired traits are gained during a person's life. Some acquired traits, such as riding a bicycle, are gained by learning. Other acquired traits, such as scars, are caused by the environment.

1492.question: Select the gas.
1492.subject: natural science
1492.lecture:
Solid, liquid, and gas are states of matter. Matter is anything that takes up space. Matter can come in different states, or forms.
When matter is a solid, it has a definite volume and a definite shape. So, a solid has a size and shape of its own.
Some solids can be easily folded, bent, or broken. A piece of paper is a solid. Also, some solids are very small. A grain of sand is a solid.
When matter is a liquid, it has a definite volume but not a definite shape. So, a liquid has a size of its own, but it does not have a shape of its own. Think about pouring juice from a bottle into a cup. The juice still takes up the same amount of space, but it takes the shape of the bottle.
Some liquids do not pour as easily as others. Honey and milk are both liquids. But pouring honey takes more time than pouring milk.
When matter is a gas, it does not have a definite volume or a definite shape. A gas expands, or gets bigger, until it completely fills a space. A gas can also get smaller if it is squeezed into a smaller space.
Many gases are invisible. Air is a gas.
1492.solution:
The air inside a soccer ball is a gas. A gas expands to fill a space. The air fills all the space inside the soccer ball. If air leaks out, it will expand into the space around the ball.
A baseball cap is a solid. A solid has a size and shape of its own. If you put a baseball cap on your head, the baseball cap will still have a size and shape of its own.
A plate is a solid. If someone drops a plate, it may break into pieces. But each piece will still have a size and shape of its own.
A ballet shoe is a solid. A solid has a size and shape of its own. When a dancer wears a ballet shoe, it may bend a little. But the ballet shoe still has a size and shape of its own.

1493.question: Which text uses the word peruse in its traditional sense?
choices: Eddie perused a clothing catalog as he waited for his appointment, flipping through the pages distractedly.
Eddie perused a catalog from his wife's favorite clothing store, searching for the perfect birthday gift.
1493.subject: language science
1493.skill: Explore words with new or contested usages
1493.lecture:
Words change in meaning when speakers begin using them in new ways. For example, the word peruse once only meant to examine in detail, but it's now also commonly used to mean to look through in a casual manner.
When a word changes in meaning, its correct usage is often debated. Although a newer sense of the word may be more commonly used, many people consider a word's traditional definition to be the correct usage. Being able to distinguish the different uses of a word can help you use it appropriately for different audiences.
Britney perused her notes, carefully preparing for her exam.
The traditional usage above is considered more standard.
David perused the magazine, absentmindedly flipping through the pages.
The nontraditional usage above is now commonly used, but traditional style guides generally advise against it.
1493.solution:
The first text uses peruse in its traditional sense: to examine in detail.
Eddie perused a catalog from his wife's favorite clothing store, searching for the perfect birthday gift.
The second text uses peruse in its nontraditional sense: to look through in a casual manner.
Eddie perused a clothing catalog as he waited for his appointment, flipping through the pages distractedly.
Most style guides recommend to use the traditional sense of the word peruse because it is considered more standard.

1494.question:
Is the following trait inherited or acquired?
Jerry has five toes on each foot.
1494.hint: Hint: Jerry was born with five toes on each foot.
1494.subject: natural science
1494.lecture:
Organisms, including people, have both inherited and acquired traits. Inherited and acquired traits are gained in different ways.
Inherited traits are passed down through families. Children gain these traits from their parents. Inherited traits do not need to be learned.
Acquired traits are gained during a person's life. Some acquired traits, such as riding a bicycle, are gained by learning. Other acquired traits, such as scars, are caused by the environment. Children do not inherit their parents' acquired traits.
1494.solution: Most humans are born with five toes on each foot. So, having five toes is an inherited trait.

1495.question: Which bird's beak is also adapted to get nectar out of long flowers?
1495.hint:
Rufous hummingbirds live in the woodlands and meadows of western North America. The shape of the 's beak is adapted to get nectar out of long flowers.
Figure: rufous hummingbird.
1495.subject: natural science
1495.skill: Animal adaptations: beaks, mouths, and necks
1495.lecture:
I will analyze the image and identify the specific adaptation of the bird's beak that is suitable for extracting nectar from long flowers. I will then compare this adaptation with the options provided to determine which bird has a similar beak adaptation.

The image shows a rufous hummingbird. Notable features include its long, thin beak, which is well-suited for reaching nectar inside long flowers. The vibrant plumage and small size are also characteristic of this species.
1495.solution: The rufous hummingbird is known for its long, thin beak, adapted for accessing nectar from long flowers. This is a specific adaptation that allows it to feed efficiently on nectar, which is its primary food source. Given this adaptation, we need to examine which of the options has a similar beak structure. The violet sabrewing also has a long, thin beak designed for reaching nectar deep in flowers, making it similar to the rufous hummingbird in this aspect. On the other hand, the common shelduck has a wide, flat beak, suited for eating plants and invertebrates in mud, making it dissimilar in adaptation. Therefore, the bird with a beak adapted like the rufous hummingbird's is the violet sabrewing.

The highlighted region lies northeast of the Philippines, separate from larger clusters of islands. This location corresponds with Palau, a country known to be situated in that part of the Pacific Ocean.

1497.question:
Which word would you find on a dictionary page with the following guide words?
shy - spool
1497.subject: language science
1497.lecture:
Guide words appear on each page of a dictionary. They tell you the first word and last word on the page. The other words on the page come between the guide words in alphabetical order.
To put words in alphabetical order, put them in order by their first letters. If the first letters are the same, look at the second letters. If the second letters are the same, look at the third letters, and so on.
If one word is shorter, and there are no more letters to compare, then the shorter word comes first in alphabetical order.
1497.solution:
Put the words in alphabetical order.
Since slippery is between the guide words shy - spool, it would be found on that page.

1498.question: Identify the question that Alvin's experiment can best answer.
choices: Does temperature affect how much bacteria can grow in liquid?
Do more bacteria grow in liquid with cinnamon than in liquid without cinnamon?
1498.hint:
The passage below describes an experiment. Read the passage and then follow the instructions below.

Alvin mixed bacteria into a nutrient-rich liquid where the bacteria could grow. He poured four ounces of the mixture into each of ten glass flasks. In five of the ten flasks, he also added one teaspoon of cinnamon. He allowed the bacteria in the flasks to grow overnight in a 37°C room. Then, Alvin used a microscope to count the number of bacteria in a small sample from each flask. He compared the amount of bacteria in the liquid with cinnamon to the amount of bacteria in the liquid without cinnamon.
Figure: flasks of liquid for growing bacteria.
1498.subject: natural science
1498.lecture:
Experiments can be designed to answer specific questions. How can you identify the questions that a certain experiment can answer? In order to do this, you need to figure out what was tested and what was measured during the experiment.
Imagine an experiment with two groups of daffodil plants. One group of plants was grown in sandy soil, and the other was grown in clay soil. Then, the height of each plant was measured.
First, identify the part of the experiment that was tested. The part of an experiment that is tested usually involves the part of the experimental setup that is different or changed. In the experiment described above, each group of plants was grown in a different type of soil. So, the effect of growing plants in different soil types was tested.
Then, identify the part of the experiment that was measured. The part of the experiment that is measured may include measurements and calculations. In the experiment described above, the heights of the plants in each group were measured.
Experiments can answer questions about how the part of the experiment that is tested affects the part that is measured. So, the experiment described above can answer questions about how soil type affects plant height.
Examples of questions that this experiment can answer include:
Does soil type affect the height of daffodil plants?
Do daffodil plants in sandy soil grow taller than daffodil plants in clay soil?
Are daffodil plants grown in sandy soil shorter than daffodil plants grown in clay soil?

1499.question: What is the capital of Vermont?
1499.subject: social science
1499.skill: Identify state capitals of the Northeast
1499.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will examine the image for relevant information regarding Vermont, identify the state highlighted, and relate it to the knowledge of U.S. state capitals. I will then choose the correct answer from the provided options.

The image is a map of the United States highlighting the state of Vermont in a darker green color compared to other states.
1499.solution: The question asks for the capital of Vermont. The map shows Vermont distinctly highlighted. Based on general knowledge, the capital of Vermont is Montpelier. Among the options provided: (A) Burlington, (B) Minneapolis, (C) Augusta, and (D) Montpelier, option (D) Montpelier is the correct capital. Burlington, another city in Vermont, is not the capital, and Minneapolis and Augusta are capitals of other states. This confirms that Montpelier is indeed Vermont's capital.

1500.question:
Complete the sentence.
The African elephant is the () land animal in the world.
1500.hint: This picture shows an African elephant.

To solve this problem, I will analyze the content of the image to understand which aspect of the animal is relevant. The focus will be on determining the size of the animal shown in the image to select the correct option.

1500.solution: The question asks about the size of the African elephant, providing options for smallest or largest. Based on common knowledge and the context given, African elephants are known as the largest land animals in the world. The options provided are: (A) smallest and (B) largest. Given their massive size, the correct answer will be (B) largest.

1501.question: Which is a run-on sentence?
choices: Listened to soft music alone in his room.
He won't get lost I will give him directions.
1501.subject: language science
1501.skill: Is it a complete sentence, a fragment, or a run-on?
1501.lecture:
A sentence is a group of words that forms a complete thought. It has both a subject and a verb.
My friends walk along the path.
A sentence fragment is a group of words that does not express a complete thought. It is usually missing a subject or a verb.
Knows the answer.
This is a sentence fragment. It is missing a subject.
Who knows the answer? She knows the answer.
The bright red car.
This is a sentence fragment. It is missing a verb.
What did the bright red car do? The bright red car stopped.
A run-on sentence is made up of two sentences that are joined without end punctuation or with just a comma.
I knocked on the door it opened.
It started raining, we ran inside.
To fix a run-on sentence, separate it into two sentences. Add end punctuation after the first sentence, and capitalize the second sentence.
I knocked on the door. It opened.
It started raining. We ran inside.
You can also fix a run-on sentence by rewriting it as a compound sentence. A compound sentence is two sentences joined by a comma and a conjunction such as and, but, or, or so.
I knocked on the door, and it opened.
It started raining, so we ran inside.
1501.solution: He won't get lost I will give him directions is a run-on sentence. It has two sentences that are joined without end punctuation: He won't get lost and I will give him directions.

1502.question:
Does this passage describe the weather or the climate?
Jeffrey lives in a town with hot summers and freezing cold winters.
1502.hint: Hint: Weather is what the atmosphere is like at a certain place and time. Climate is the pattern of weather in a certain place.
1502.subject: natural science
1502.skill: What's the difference between weather and climate?
1502.lecture:
The atmosphere is the layer of air that surrounds Earth. Both weather and climate tell you about the atmosphere.
Weather is what the atmosphere is like at a certain place and time. Weather can change quickly. For example, the temperature outside your house might get higher throughout the day.
Climate is the pattern of weather in a certain place. For example, summer temperatures in New York are usually higher than winter temperatures.
1502.solution:
Read the text carefully.
Jeffrey lives in a town with hot summers and freezing cold winters.
This passage tells you about the usual temperatures where Jeffrey lives. It does not describe what the weather is like on a particular day. So, this passage describes the climate.

1503.question: Which property do these three objects have in common?
1503.subject: natural science
1503.lecture:
An object has different properties. A property of an object can tell you how it looks, feels, tastes, or smells. Properties can also tell you how an object will behave when something happens to it.
Different objects can have properties in common. You can use these properties to put objects into groups.
1503.solution:
Look at each object.
For each object, decide if it has that property.
A rough object feels scratchy when you touch it. The rain boots and the rubber duck are not rough.
A sticky object can attach or stick to other things. The rain boots and the rubber duck are not sticky.
Yellow is a color.
This color is yellow. All three objects are yellow.
The property that all three objects have in common is yellow.

1504.question: Which text uses the word peruse in its traditional sense?
choices: Herman perused a clothing catalog as he waited for his appointment, flipping through the pages distractedly.
Herman perused a catalog from his wife's favorite clothing store, searching for the perfect birthday gift.
1504.subject: language science
1504.skill: Explore words with new or contested usages
1504.lecture:
Words change in meaning when speakers begin using them in new ways. For example, the word peruse once only meant to examine in detail, but it's now also commonly used to mean to look through in a casual manner.
When a word changes in meaning, its correct usage is often debated. Although a newer sense of the word may be more commonly used, many people consider a word's traditional definition to be the correct usage. Being able to distinguish the different uses of a word can help you use it appropriately for different audiences.
Britney perused her notes, carefully preparing for her exam.
The traditional usage above is considered more standard.
David perused the magazine, absentmindedly flipping through the pages.
The nontraditional usage above is now commonly used, but traditional style guides generally advise against it.
1504.solution:
The first text uses peruse in its traditional sense: to examine in detail.
Herman perused a catalog from his wife's favorite clothing store, searching for the perfect birthday gift.
The second text uses peruse in its nontraditional sense: to look through in a casual manner.
Herman perused a clothing catalog as he waited for his appointment, flipping through the pages distractedly.
Most style guides recommend to use the traditional sense of the word peruse because it is considered more standard.

1505.question:
Does this passage describe the weather or the climate?
The Atacama Desert in Chile is one of the driest places on Earth. It has an average precipitation of only 1.5 centimeters per year.
1505.hint: Hint: Weather is what the atmosphere is like at a certain place and time. Climate is the pattern of weather in a certain place.
1505.subject: natural science
1505.skill: What's the difference between weather and climate?
1505.lecture:
The atmosphere is the layer of air that surrounds Earth. Both weather and climate tell you about the atmosphere.
Weather is what the atmosphere is like at a certain place and time. Weather can change quickly. For example, the temperature outside your house might get higher throughout the day.
Climate is the pattern of weather in a certain place. For example, summer temperatures in New York are usually higher than winter temperatures.
1505.solution:
Read the text carefully.
The Atacama Desert in Chile is one of the driest places on Earth. It has an average precipitation of only 1.5 centimeters per year.
This passage tells you about the usual precipitation in the Atacama Desert. It does not describe what the weather is like on a particular day. So, this passage describes the climate.

1506.question: Which animal's skin is better adapted as a warning sign to ward off predators?
1506.hint:
Golden dart frogs have poisonous glands in their brightly colored skin. The bright color serves as a warning sign that the animal is poisonous. The 's skin is adapted to ward off predators.
Figure: golden dart frog.
1506.subject: natural science
1506.skill: Animal adaptations: skins and body coverings
1506.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will examine the image of the animal, using details from its appearance to identify adaptations that serve as a warning to predators. I will compare this with the given options to determine the correct answer.

The image shows a golden poison dart frog. It is small, with bright yellow skin and black eyes. The brightly colored skin is a characteristic feature aimed at deterring predators by signaling its toxicity.
1506.solution: The golden dart frog is known for its vivid yellow skin, which is an adaptation for warding off predators by indicating its poisonous nature. This kind of warning coloration is known as aposematism. To find a similar adaptation among the options, we compare the flamboyant cuttlefish and the lechwe. The flamboyant cuttlefish has a brightly colored body and is also poisonous, serving as a warning to predators. In contrast, the lechwe has plain, light-brown fur that does not serve as a warning. Therefore, the flamboyant cuttlefish shares the adaptive trait of using skin coloration as a warning against predators.

1507.question:
Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
Mayor Kelley wants to create more bicycle lanes in Greenwood. However, many citizens of Greenwood live far from work. It would not be realistic to force us to give up our cars and bike everywhere.
choices: straw man: a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against
appeal to nature: the assumption that natural things are always good
circular reasoning: an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
1507.subject: language science
1507.lecture:
A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand, it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.
A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument, rather than the argument itself
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together, one caused the other
false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against
1507.solution: The text argues that Mayor Kelley wants people to give up their cars. However, this misrepresents Mayor Kelley's argument. Mayor Kelley only wants to create more bike lanes. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a straw man.

1508.question: What is the expected ratio of offspring that have coat graying to offspring that do not have coat graying? Choose the most likely ratio.
1508.hint:
This passage describes the coat graying trait in horses:
Your hair may turn gray or white as you grow older. Some horses go through a similar process called coat graying as they age. These horses are usually a darker color, such as brown or black, when they are born. Over time, the hairs of their coats lose their original color and become gray or white.
In a group of horses, some individuals have coat graying and others do not. In this group, the gene for the coat graying trait has two alleles. The allele for having a graying coat (G) is dominant over the allele for not having a graying coat (g).
This Punnett square shows a cross between two horses.This Punnett square is Gg

Gg

Gg

Gg
1508.subject: natural science
1508.skill: Use Punnett squares to calculate ratios of offspring types
1508.lecture:
I will analyze the Punnett square to determine the expected ratio of offspring with the coat graying trait to those without it by identifying the genotypes and their corresponding phenotypes based on the dominance of alleles.

The image depicts a Punnett square showing a genetic cross between two horses. Each box contains the genotype Gg, indicating the presence of one dominant allele for coat graying (G) and one recessive allele (g).
1508.solution: The gene for coat graying has two alleles: G (dominant) and g (recessive). A graying coat is a dominant trait, so any offspring with at least one G allele (GG or Gg) will exhibit this trait. The Punnett square shows all offspring have genotype Gg, meaning they all possess the graying trait. There are zero boxes with genotype gg, which would indicate the recessive trait. Therefore, all offspring have the dominant phenotype.

1510.question: Compare the average kinetic energies of the particles in each sample. Which sample has the higher temperature?
choices: neither; the samples have the same temperature
1510.hint: The diagrams below show two pure samples of gas in identical closed, rigid containers. Each colored ball represents one gas particle. Both samples have the same number of particles.
1510.subject: natural science
1510.skill: Identify how particle motion affects temperature and pressure
1510.lecture:
To compare the average kinetic energies and determine which sample has the higher temperature, I'll examine the mass and speed of particles in each sample. I'll use these values to calculate and compare the kinetic energies, as temperature is related to average kinetic energy.

The image shows two jars, each containing a gas sample. Sample A has particles with a mass of 40 u and an average speed of 1,100 m/s. Sample B has particles with a mass of 46 u and the same average speed of 1,100 m/s. Both jars have the same number of particles.
1510.solution:
The average kinetic energy of particles in a gas is given by the formula \( KE = \frac{1}{2} m v^2 \), where \( m \) is the mass of the particles and \( v \) is their speed. 
- For both samples, the speed \( v \) is 1,100 m/s.
- In Sample A, each particle has a mass of 40 u.
- In Sample B, each particle has a mass of 46 u.
- Since both samples have the same speed, kinetic energy depends on the mass.
- Sample B has particles with greater mass, resulting in higher kinetic energy compared to Sample A.
- The temperature of a gas is proportional to the average kinetic energy of its particles. Therefore, the sample with higher average kinetic energy will have a higher temperature.

1511.hint: Conglomerate is a type of rock. It is made up of grains of many different sizes, such as sand, mud, and pebbles. Conglomerate forms when layers of these sediments are pressed together to form rock.

The image displays a rock composed of variously sized rounded clasts such as pebbles and stones, cemented together in a matrix.
1511.solution: Conglomerate rocks are characterized by their composition of mixed sediment sizes such as sand, mud, and pebbles that are compacted together. Based on the appearance of the rounded clasts joined together in the image, the rock is a typical example of conglomerate. According to the context and the standard answer, sedimentary rocks are formed from the layering and compaction of sediments. Given the characteristics observed, conglomerate fits the description of a sedimentary rock, as it forms from the compaction of differentiated sediments.

Two magnets are placed as shown.

Hint: Magnets that attract pull together. Magnets that repel push apart.
1512.subject: natural science
1512.skill: Identify magnets that attract or repel
1512.lecture:
Magnets can pull or push on each other without touching. When magnets attract, they pull together. When magnets repel, they push apart.
Whether a magnet attracts or repels other magnets depends on the positions of its poles, or ends. Every magnet has two poles, called north and south.
Here are some examples of magnets. The north pole of each magnet is marked N, and the south pole is marked S.
If different poles are closest to each other, the magnets attract. The magnets in the pair below attract.
If the same poles are closest to each other, the magnets repel. The magnets in both pairs below repel.
1512.solution:
Will these magnets attract or repel? To find out, look at which poles are closest to each other.
The south pole of one magnet is closest to the north pole of the other magnet. Poles that are different attract. So, these magnets will attract each other.

1513.question: Select the fish.
1513.subject: natural science
1513.skill: Identify mammals, birds, fish, reptiles, and amphibians
1513.lecture: Fish live underwater. They have fins, not limbs.
1513.solution:
A gharial is a reptile. It has scaly, waterproof skin.
Gharials are a type of crocodile. Gharials live near rivers and eat fish.
A zebra is a mammal. It has hair and feeds its young milk.
Zebras eat mostly grass. But they sometimes eat other types of plants, such as shrubs or tree bark.
A humpback whale is a mammal. It has hair and feeds its young milk.
Whales are mammals that live in the ocean. Humpback whales have small hairs that grow from bumps around their mouth.
A piranha is a fish. It lives underwater. It has fins, not limbs.
Piranhas have sharp teeth. Piranhas hunt in groups. A group of piranhas can eat a large animal.

1514.question:
Is the following trait inherited or acquired?
Jen has a scar on her left knee.
1514.hint: Hint: Most scars are caused by accidents during a person's life.
1514.subject: natural science
1514.lecture:
Organisms, including people, have both inherited and acquired traits. Inherited and acquired traits are gained in different ways.
Inherited traits are passed down through families. Children gain these traits from their parents. Inherited traits do not need to be learned.
Acquired traits are gained during a person's life. Some acquired traits, such as riding a bicycle, are gained by learning. Other acquired traits, such as scars, are caused by the environment. Children do not inherit their parents' acquired traits.
1514.solution: Children do not inherit their parent's scars. Instead, scars are caused by the environment. People can get scars after they get hurt. So, having a scar is an acquired trait.

Maps have four cardinal directions, or main directions. Those directions are north, south, east, and west.
A compass rose is a set of arrows that point to the cardinal directions. A compass rose usually shows only the first letter of each cardinal direction.
The north arrow points to the North Pole. On most maps, north is at the top of the map.
1515.solution: To find the answer, look at the compass rose. Look at which way the east arrow is pointing. Delaware is farthest east.

Organisms, including people, have both inherited and acquired traits. Inherited and acquired traits are gained in different ways.
Inherited traits are passed down through families. Children gain these traits from their parents. Inherited traits do not need to be learned.
Acquired traits are gained during a person's life. Some acquired traits, such as riding a bicycle, are gained by learning. Other acquired traits, such as scars, are caused by the environment. Children do not inherit their parents' acquired traits.
1516.solution: Children do not inherit their parent's scars. Instead, scars are caused by the environment. People can get scars after they get hurt. So, having a scar is an acquired trait.

Scientific names are written in italics, but common names are usually not. The first word of the scientific name is capitalized, and the second word is not. For example, the common name of the animal below is giant panda. Its scientific name is Ailuropoda melanoleuca.

1520.question: Which of the following contains a vague pronoun reference?
choices: Mr. Garza was reaching for the ladle in the gravy bowl when his wife took it away.
Mr. Garza was reaching for the ladle in the gravy bowl when his wife took the ladle away.
1520.subject: language science
1520.lecture:
When writing, make sure to avoid vague pronoun references. A vague pronoun reference occurs when a pronoun could refer to more than one possible antecedent.
When Lisa and Kim finally landed, she breathed a sigh of relief.
The pronoun she could refer to either Lisa or Kim, so the meaning of the sentence is unclear.
Vague pronoun references can be corrected in one of two ways:
1. Replace the pronoun with its correct antecedent:
When Lisa and Kim finally landed, Lisa breathed a sigh of relief.
2. Rewrite the sentence:
Lisa breathed a sigh of relief when she and Kim finally landed.
A vague pronoun reference also occurs when they, them, their, theirs, it, or its is used without its antecedent.
They say that this nail polish dries in less than five minutes.
The pronoun they is used without its antecedent, so the meaning of the sentence is unclear.
This problem can be fixed by replacing the pronoun with its missing antecedent.
The advertisements say that this nail polish dries in less than five minutes.
1520.solution:
The second answer choice contains a vague pronoun reference. The pronoun it could refer to the ladle or the gravy bowl.
The first answer choice shows a possible correction for the vague pronoun reference. It has been replaced with the ladle.
Mr. Garza was reaching for the ladle in the gravy bowl when his wife took the ladle away.

1521.question: How long is a grain of rice?
1521.subject: natural science
1521.skill: Choose metric units of distance, mass, and volume
1521.lecture:
Measurements are written with both a number and a unit. The unit comes after the number. The unit shows what the number means.
When you are using metric units, length can be written with units of millimeters, centimeters, meters, or kilometers. One meter contains 100 centimeters or 1,000 millimeters. So, 1 meter is larger than 1 centimeter, and 1 centimeter is larger than 1 millimeter.
The tip of the pencil shown here is only 1 millimeter wide, but the pencil is about 16 centimeters long.
A red fox is about 1 meter long. The Sydney Harbour Bridge in Australia is about 1,000 meters, or 1 kilometer, in length.
1521.solution:
The best estimate for the length of a grain of rice is 4 millimeters.
4 centimeters, 4 meters, and 4 kilometers are all too long.

1522.question:
Complete the sentence.
An icicle forming on the edge of a roof is a ().
1522.subject: natural science
1522.lecture:
Chemical changes and physical changes are two common ways matter can change.
In a chemical change, the type of matter changes. The types of matter before and after a chemical change are always different.
Burning a piece of paper is a chemical change. When paper gets hot enough, it reacts with oxygen in the air and burns. The paper and oxygen change into ash and smoke.
In a physical change, the type of matter stays the same. The types of matter before and after a physical change are always the same.
Cutting a piece of paper is a physical change. The cut pieces are still made of paper.
A change of state is a type of physical change. For example, ice melting is a physical change. Ice and liquid water are made of the same type of matter: water.
1522.solution: An icicle forming on the edge of a roof is a change of state. So, it is a physical change. Liquid water freezes and becomes solid, but it is still made of water. A different type of matter is not formed.

1530.question: Think about the magnetic force between the magnets in each pair. Which of the following statements is true?
choices: The magnitude of the magnetic force is greater in Pair 1.
The magnitude of the magnetic force is greater in Pair 2.
The magnitude of the magnetic force is the same in both pairs.
1530.hint: The images below show two pairs of magnets. The magnets in different pairs do not affect each other. All the magnets shown are made of the same material, but some of them are different shapes.
1530.subject: natural science
1530.lecture:
I will examine the image to determine the orientation and size of the magnets in each pair. Then I will use the properties of magnetic force to answer the question regarding the magnitude of force between the magnets.

The image shows two pairs of magnets. In Pair 1, both magnets have a rectangular shape with similar dimensions, and their north (N) poles face each other. In Pair 2, the magnets are the same shape as in Pair 1, but their south (S) and north (N) poles face each other, causing repulsion. In both pairs, the labeled magnets are separated by the same distance of 11.1 mm.
1530.solution: Magnetic force depends on factors such as the size and distance between the magnets, not whether they attract or repel. Both pairs of magnets have the same shape and size, and they are separated by the same distance. Therefore, the magnitude of the magnetic force in each pair is determined by these consistent factors rather than whether the magnets are attracting or repelling. The interaction direction, whether attraction or repulsion, does not impact the magnitude. Hence, the magnitude of the magnetic force is the same for both pairs.

1531.question: Which mug of cider has a lower temperature?
choices: the mug of cider with less thermal energy
the mug of cider with more thermal energy
1531.hint: Two 150-gram mugs of cider are identical except for their thermal energies.
1531.subject: natural science
1531.skill: How are temperature and mass related to thermal energy?
1531.lecture:
Matter is made of tiny particles called atoms. Atoms are always moving.
The energy of moving atoms is called thermal energy. The total amount of thermal energy in matter depends on three things: the type of matter, the amount of matter, and how fast the atoms are moving.
Temperature measures how hot or cold matter is. If the atoms in matter slow down, the temperature goes down. The matter now has both less thermal energy and a lower temperature.
What happens if the amount of matter changes? A 2-kilogram brick at 70°F has twice as much thermal energy as a 1-kilogram brick at 70°F. The two bricks have the same temperature, but the larger brick has twice as many atoms. So, it has twice as much thermal energy.
1531.solution: The two mugs of cider are made of the same material and have the same mass. So, the mug of cider with less thermal energy has a lower temperature.

1534.question: Which solution has a higher concentration of blue particles?
choices: neither; their concentrations are the same
1534.hint: The diagram below is a model of two solutions. Each blue ball represents one particle of solute.
1534.subject: natural science
1534.lecture:
A solution is made up of two or more substances that are completely mixed. In a solution, solute particles are mixed into a solvent. The solute cannot be separated from the solvent by a filter. For example, if you stir a spoonful of salt into a cup of water, the salt will mix into the water to make a saltwater solution. In this case, the salt is the solute. The water is the solvent.
The concentration of a solute in a solution is a measure of the ratio of solute to solvent. Concentration can be described in terms of particles of solute per volume of solvent.
concentration = particles of solute / volume of solvent
1534.solution:
In Solution A and Solution B, the blue particles represent the solute. To figure out which solution has a higher concentration of blue particles, look at both the number of blue particles and the volume of the solvent in each container.
Use the concentration formula to find the number of blue particles per milliliter.
Solution A has more blue particles per milliliter. So, Solution A has a higher concentration of blue particles.
