Therefore, the dark green state is New Jersey.

1562.question: Based on this information, what is Toriel's phenotype for the coat color trait?
1562.hint:
In a group of horses, some individuals have a black coat and others have a reddish-brown coat. In this group, the gene for the coat color trait has two alleles. The allele for a reddish-brown coat (l) is recessive to the allele for a black coat (L).
Toriel is a horse from this group. Toriel has the homozygous genotype LL for the coat color gene.
1562.subject: natural science
1562.solution:
Toriel's genotype for the coat color gene is LL. Toriel's genotype of LL has only L allelles. The L allele is for a black coat. So, Toriel's phenotype for the coat color trait must be a black coat.
To check this answer, consider whether Toriel's alleles are dominant or recessive. The allele for a reddish-brown coat (l) is recessive to the allele for a black coat (L). This means L is a dominant allele, and l is a recessive allele.
Toriel's genotype of LL has two dominant alleles. An organism with at least one dominant allele for a gene will have the dominant allele's version of the trait. So, Toriel's phenotype for the coat color trait must be a black coat.

1563.question: Select the vertebrate.
1563.hint: Hint: Mammals, birds, fish, reptiles, and amphibians are vertebrates.
1563.subject: natural science
1563.lecture:
Vertebrates and invertebrates are both groups of animals.
A vertebrate has a backbone. The backbone is made of many bones in an animal's back. A vertebrate's backbone helps connect the different parts of its body. In the drawings below, each vertebrate's backbone is colored orange.
An invertebrate does not have a backbone. In fact, invertebrates do not have any bones! Some invertebrates have an outer cover on their body called an exoskeleton. Other invertebrates have a soft body.
1563.solution:
Like other tarantulas, a red-kneed tarantula is an invertebrate. It does not have a backbone. It has an exoskeleton.
Like other octopuses, a giant octopus is an invertebrate. It does not have a backbone. It has a soft body.
A castor bean tick is an insect. Like other insects, a castor bean tick is an invertebrate. It does not have a backbone. It has an exoskeleton.
A red-tailed hawk is a bird. Like other birds, a red-tailed hawk is a vertebrate. It has a backbone.

1564.question: Select the deep sea ecosystem.
choices:
This ecosystem has:
water at the bottom of the ocean
no sunlight
organisms that crawl or stick to the ground

This ecosystem has:
shallow, salty water
bright sunlight
many different types of organisms
1564.subject: natural science
1564.lecture:
An environment includes all of the biotic, or living, and abiotic, or nonliving, things in an area. An ecosystem is created by the relationships that form among the biotic and abiotic parts of an environment.
There are many different types of ecosystems. Here are some ways in which these ecosystems can differ from each other:
the pattern of weather, or climate
the type of soil or water
the organisms that live there
1564.solution:
A deep sea is a type of ecosystem. It has water at the bottom of the ocean, no sunlight, and organisms that crawl or stick to the ground.
Choice 1 is a deep sea ecosystem. It is at the bottom of the ocean. It is so far underwater that no sunlight can reach it.
Choice 2 is a tropical coral reef ecosystem. It has shallow water and many different types of organisms.

1565.question: Which ping pong ball has a higher temperature?
choices: the ping pong ball with more thermal energy
the ping pong ball with less thermal energy
1565.hint: Two ping pong balls are identical except for their thermal energies.
1565.subject: natural science
1565.skill: How are temperature and mass related to thermal energy?
1565.lecture:
Matter is made of tiny particles called atoms. Atoms are always moving.
The energy of moving atoms is called thermal energy. The total amount of thermal energy in matter depends on three things: the type of matter, the amount of matter, and how fast the atoms are moving.
Temperature measures how hot or cold matter is. If the atoms in matter move faster, the temperature goes up. The matter now has both more thermal energy and a higher temperature.
What happens if the amount of matter changes? A 2-kilogram brick at 70°F has twice as much thermal energy as a 1-kilogram brick at 70°F. The two bricks have the same temperature, but the larger brick has twice as many atoms. So, it has twice as much thermal energy.
1565.solution: The two ping pong balls are made of the same material and have the same mass. So, the ping pong ball with more thermal energy has a higher temperature.

1566.question: Which property matches this object?
1566.subject: natural science
1566.lecture:
To solve the problem, I'll examine the image to determine the relevant properties of the object depicted. I'll use logical reasoning to match the object with the most appropriate property provided in the options.

The image shows a strip of Velcro, consisting of two parts: one with small hooks and another with matching loops. These strips are generally used to fasten items together.
1566.solution: Velcro is known for its distinctive texture. The hook side of Velcro feels rough and can be described as scratchy, as it can be abrasive against the skin. On the other hand, shiny typically refers to a smooth surface that reflects light, which does not apply to Velcro. Therefore, the property that best matches Velcro is scratchy.

1567.question: Compare the average kinetic energies of the particles in each sample. Which sample has the higher temperature?
choices: neither; the samples have the same temperature
1567.hint: The diagrams below show two pure samples of gas in identical closed, rigid containers. Each colored ball represents one gas particle. Both samples have the same number of particles.
1567.subject: natural science
1567.skill: Identify how particle motion affects temperature and pressure
1567.lecture:
To solve the problem, I'll determine which gas sample has the higher temperature by comparing their average kinetic energies, which are affected by the mass and speed of the particles. I will outline the reasoning based on the image and context provided to reach the final answer.

The image shows two jars labeled Sample A and Sample B, each containing gas particles. Sample A has particles with a mass of 28 u and an average speed of 1,800 m/s. Sample B has particles with a mass of 34 u and the same average speed of 1,800 m/s. The number of particles in both samples is the same.
1567.solution:
The temperature of a gas is directly related to the average kinetic energy of its particles. Kinetic energy is calculated using the formula \(\frac{1}{2}mv^2\), where \(m\) is the mass of a particle and \(v\) is its speed. Both samples have particles moving at the same average speed of 1,800 m/s. However, the mass of the particles differs: 28 u for Sample A and 34 u for Sample B.

Since kinetic energy is proportional to both mass and the square of speed, particles with higher mass will have higher kinetic energy if the speed is constant. Therefore, with Sample B's particles having greater mass than Sample A's, Sample B’s particles have a higher average kinetic energy.

Since temperature correlates directly with average kinetic energy, Sample B must have the higher temperature.

1568.question: Identify the question that Simon's experiment can best answer.
choices: Does temperature affect how much bacteria can grow in liquid?
Do more bacteria grow in liquid with cinnamon than in liquid without cinnamon?
1568.hint:
The passage below describes an experiment. Read the passage and then follow the instructions below.

Simon mixed bacteria into a nutrient-rich liquid where the bacteria could grow. He poured four ounces of the mixture into each of ten glass flasks. In five of the ten flasks, he also added one teaspoon of cinnamon. He allowed the bacteria in the flasks to grow overnight in a 37°C room. Then, Simon used a microscope to count the number of bacteria in a small sample from each flask. He compared the amount of bacteria in the liquid with cinnamon to the amount of bacteria in the liquid without cinnamon.
Figure: flasks of liquid for growing bacteria.
1568.subject: natural science
1568.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will first identify the components of Simon's experiment, specifically focusing on what was tested and measured. Then, I will determine which of the given options corresponds to these aspects.

The image shows glass flasks containing a yellowish liquid, possibly a nutrient-rich medium for growing bacteria. Some flasks have been covered with aluminum foil, likely to maintain sterile conditions.
1568.solution: Simon's experiment involved adding bacteria to a nutrient-rich liquid, with half of the flasks also containing cinnamon. The test involved observing the effect of cinnamon on bacterial growth. The variable tested was the presence of cinnamon, and the variable measured was the number of bacteria. Therefore, the experiment is designed to answer if cinnamon affects bacterial growth. This aligns with option B: "Do more bacteria grow in liquid with cinnamon than in liquid without cinnamon?" Option A involves temperature, which wasn't a variable Simon changed in this experiment.

1569.question: What is the capital of Colorado?
1569.subject: social science
1569.skill: Identify state capitals of the West
1569.solution: Denver is the capital of Colorado.

1570.question:
Why might raising cubs with other lionesses in a pride increase an African lioness's reproductive success? Complete the claim below that answers this question and is best supported by the passage.
Raising cubs with other lionesses in a pride increases the chances that ().
choices: the lioness's cubs will be around other cubs
the lioness's cubs will survive attacks
the lioness will feed the cubs of other lionesses
1570.hint:
Animals often behave in certain ways that can increase their reproductive success. Read the passage about a specific animal behavior. Then, follow the instructions below.

African lions live in groups called prides. In a pride, female lions, or lionesses, may give birth to cubs around the same time. When this happens, the lionesses help raise each other's cubs. The lionesses work together to feed and protect all the cubs for about two years.
Lionesses have to protect their cubs from male lions that are not part of their pride. These male lions may attack and kill the cubs to try to take over the pride. When a pride has multiple lionesses, the cubs are less likely to be killed in an attack. When a pride has only one lioness, the cubs are more likely to be killed.
Figure: African lionesses and their cubs.
1570.subject: natural science
1570.skill: How can animal behaviors affect reproductive success? Identify evidence to support a claim
1570.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will analyze the context and image to determine how raising cubs with other lionesses in a pride can increase reproductive success. I'll compare the options given for a well-supported conclusion.

The image shows a group of African lionesses and their cubs resting together on grassland. The presence of multiple lionesses suggests a communal effort in protecting and nurturing the cubs.
1570.solution: The passage describes that lionesses in a pride give birth around the same time and collectively care for all the cubs. This joint effort helps protect the cubs from male lions outside the pride who might kill them. With multiple lionesses, the cubs have a higher chance of surviving such attacks, thus increasing the reproductive success of each lioness. The key aspect that directly relates to increased reproductive success is the enhanced protection the cubs receive, which is option B.

1571.question:
Is there a sentence fragment?
We called a taxi for Mr. McClure. Whose car was towed from the no-parking zone in front of the firehouse.
1571.subject: language science
1571.lecture:
A sentence is a group of words that expresses a complete thought.
The band I'm in has been rehearsing daily because we have a concert in two weeks.
A sentence fragment is a group of words that does not express a complete thought.
Rehearsing daily because we have a concert in two weeks.
This fragment is missing a subject. It doesn't tell who is rehearsing.
The band I'm in.
This fragment is missing a verb. It doesn't tell what the band I'm in is doing.
Because we have a concert in two weeks.
This fragment is missing an independent clause. It doesn't tell what happened because of the concert.
1571.solution:
There is a sentence fragment that does not express a complete thought.
We called a taxi for Mr. McClure. Whose car was towed from the no-parking zone in front of the firehouse.
Here is one way to fix the sentence fragment:
We called a taxi for Mr. McClure, whose car was towed from the no-parking zone in front of the firehouse.

1572.question: Which closing is correct for a letter?
1572.subject: language science
1572.lecture:
A letter starts with a greeting and ends with a closing. For each one, capitalize the first word and end with a comma. You should also capitalize proper nouns, such as Aunt Sue.
Dear Aunt Sue,
I'm glad you could come to my party, and
thank you for the birthday gift. I could not have
asked for a better one! Every time I see it, I think
of you.
With love,
Rory
1572.solution:
The second closing is correct:
Its first word is capitalized, and it ends with a comma.

1573.question:
Which figure of speech is used in this text?
After basketball practice, I was so hungry that I could have eaten a horse.
1573.subject: language science
1573.skill: Classify figures of speech: euphemism, hyperbole, oxymoron, paradox
1573.lecture:
Figures of speech are words or phrases that use language in a nonliteral or unusual way. They can make writing more expressive.
A euphemism is a polite or indirect expression that is used to de-emphasize an unpleasant topic.
The head of Human Resources would never refer to firing people, only to laying them off.
Hyperbole is an obvious exaggeration that is not meant to be taken literally.
I ate so much that I think I might explode!
An oxymoron is a joining of two seemingly contradictory terms.
Some reviewers are calling this book a new classic.
A paradox is a statement that might at first appear to be contradictory, but that may in fact contain some truth.
Always expect the unexpected.
1573.solution:
The text uses hyperbole, an obvious exaggeration that is not meant to be taken literally.
Could have eaten a horse is an exaggeration, since it is unlikely that someone could eat an entire horse.

1574.question: What is the capital of Massachusetts?
1574.subject: social science
1574.skill: Identify state capitals of the Northeast
1574.solution: Boston is the capital of Massachusetts.

1575.question: Identify the question that Juan's experiment can best answer.
choices: Do more bacteria grow in liquid with cinnamon than in liquid without cinnamon?
Does temperature affect how much bacteria can grow in liquid?
1575.hint:
The passage below describes an experiment. Read the passage and then follow the instructions below.

Juan mixed bacteria into a nutrient-rich liquid where the bacteria could grow. He poured four ounces of the mixture into each of ten glass flasks. In five of the ten flasks, he also added one teaspoon of cinnamon. He allowed the bacteria in the flasks to grow overnight in a 37°C room. Then, Juan used a microscope to count the number of bacteria in a small sample from each flask. He compared the amount of bacteria in the liquid with cinnamon to the amount of bacteria in the liquid without cinnamon.
Figure: flasks of liquid for growing bacteria.
1575.subject: natural science
1575.lecture:
Experiments can be designed to answer specific questions. How can you identify the questions that a certain experiment can answer? In order to do this, you need to figure out what was tested and what was measured during the experiment.
Imagine an experiment with two groups of daffodil plants. One group of plants was grown in sandy soil, and the other was grown in clay soil. Then, the height of each plant was measured.
First, identify the part of the experiment that was tested. The part of an experiment that is tested usually involves the part of the experimental setup that is different or changed. In the experiment described above, each group of plants was grown in a different type of soil. So, the effect of growing plants in different soil types was tested.
Then, identify the part of the experiment that was measured. The part of the experiment that is measured may include measurements and calculations. In the experiment described above, the heights of the plants in each group were measured.
Experiments can answer questions about how the part of the experiment that is tested affects the part that is measured. So, the experiment described above can answer questions about how soil type affects plant height.
Examples of questions that this experiment can answer include:
Does soil type affect the height of daffodil plants?
Do daffodil plants in sandy soil grow taller than daffodil plants in clay soil?
Are daffodil plants grown in sandy soil shorter than daffodil plants grown in clay soil?

1576.question: Identify the question that Erin's experiment can best answer.
choices: Do slugs eat more from tomato leaves or broccoli leaves?
Do slugs weigh more after eating tomato leaves or broccoli leaves?
1576.hint:
The passage below describes an experiment. Read the passage and then follow the instructions below.

Erin cut tomato and broccoli plant leaves into one-inch squares. In each of 12 containers, she placed six leaf squares: three tomato-leaf squares and three broccoli-leaf squares. She put one slug from her garden into each container. After two days, Erin measured the amount of each leaf square that had been eaten by the slugs. She compared the amount that had been eaten from the tomato-leaf squares to the amount that had been eaten from the broccoli-leaf squares.
Figure: a slug on a leaf.
1576.subject: natural science
1576.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will analyze the experimental setup to identify what was tested and measured. This will guide me to determine which question the experiment can best answer.

The image shows a slug on a leaf, highlighting the subject of Erin's experiment, which involves slugs and leaves.
1576.solution: In Erin's experiment, she used leaves from tomato and broccoli plants, placing them in containers with slugs. The purpose was to observe which leaves the slugs consumed more over two days. The variables include the type of leaf (tomato or broccoli) and the amount eaten. Erin measured and compared the quantity of leaf eaten by the slugs. Therefore, the experiment tests the slugs' eating preference between tomato and broccoli leaves, as it involves measuring how much of each type of leaf is consumed. The question that aligns with what was tested and measured is: "Do slugs eat more from tomato leaves or broccoli leaves?" Since the experiment's focus is on consumption rather than determining any change in slug weight, question A is the most appropriate.

1577.question: Which sentence is more formal?
choices: There are some things that Ms. Campbell wants to bring up at the next city council meeting.
Ms. Campbell has several important proposals to discuss at the next city council meeting.
1577.subject: language science
1577.lecture:
Formal writing is used for essays, business letters, and reports. The following types of informal language should be avoided in formal writing:
Type | Examples
slang | cool, awesome
idioms | knock your socks off
conversational language | gonna, kinda, yeah
abbreviated language | ASAP, FYI
overly simple or imprecise language | he got some stuff at the store
contractions | can't, won't
Contractions are not as informal as the other types, but they should be used sparingly in formal writing.
Compare the following sentences. The first is informal. The second is formal.
Informal: Yeah, ostriches can't fly, but they're awesome runners.
Formal: Though ostriches are flightless, they are remarkably adept runners.
1577.solution:
The second sentence is less formal. You can tell because it uses overly simple or imprecise language (some things, bring up).
The first sentence uses more precise language, so it is more formal overall.

1578.question: Select the animal.
1578.subject: natural science
1578.lecture:
Plants and animals are living things. Living things are called organisms.
Plants come in many shapes and sizes. Most plants grow in the ground. They might grow leaves, flowers, and fruit. Plants cannot move around on their own like animals can.
Animals also come in many shapes and sizes. Most animals can move around. Animals might run, swim, jump, or fly. Animals eat plants or other organisms for food.
1578.solution:
A fig tree is a plant. It has many leaves.
Fig trees grow in dry, sunny places.
A ladybug is an animal. It walks and flies.
Some ladybugs have spots. Other types of ladybugs have stripes!

1579.question: Identify the question that Brittany's experiment can best answer.
choices: Does the humidity level where tomato seeds are planted affect the number of tomato seedlings that grow?
Do more tomato seedlings grow when they are planted in soil with fertilizer compared to soil without fertilizer?
1579.hint:
The passage below describes an experiment. Read the passage and then follow the instructions below.

Brittany planted 25 tomato seeds one-half inch below the soil surface in each of six pots. Brittany added an equal amount of fertilizer to three of the six pots. She placed the pots in a plant growth chamber where all the seeds experienced the same temperature, amount of light, and humidity level. After two weeks, Brittany counted the number of seedlings that grew in each pot. She compared the number of seedlings in the pots with fertilizer to the number of seedlings in the pots without fertilizer.
Figure: tomato seedlings growing in soil.
1579.subject: natural science
1579.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will analyze Brittany's experiment and identify the variables tested and measured. This will help determine which question the experiment can best answer.

The image shows tomato seedlings growing in the soil, representing Brittany's experiment, which tested the effects of fertilizer on seedling growth.
1579.solution: The experiment involves two groups: one with fertilizer and one without. The variable tested is the presence of fertilizer. Brittany counted the number of seedlings, making it the measured variable. This setup tests whether fertilizer affects the number of seedlings grown, aligning with option (B). Option (A) involves humidity, which remains constant in Brittany's setup and is not tested. Therefore, the experiment specifically answers if more seedlings grow with fertilizer.

1580.question: Which of the following contains a vague pronoun reference?
choices: Mr. Warren wanted the new employees to fill out their intake forms, but he couldn't find the forms.
Mr. Warren wanted the new employees to fill out their intake forms, but he couldn't find them.
1580.subject: language science
1580.lecture:
When writing, make sure to avoid vague pronoun references. A vague pronoun reference occurs when a pronoun could refer to more than one possible antecedent.
When Lisa and Kim finally landed, she breathed a sigh of relief.
The pronoun she could refer to either Lisa or Kim, so the meaning of the sentence is unclear.
Vague pronoun references can be corrected in one of two ways:
1. Replace the pronoun with its correct antecedent:
When Lisa and Kim finally landed, Lisa breathed a sigh of relief.
2. Rewrite the sentence:
Lisa breathed a sigh of relief when she and Kim finally landed.
A vague pronoun reference also occurs when they, them, their, theirs, it, or its is used without its antecedent.
They say that this nail polish dries in less than five minutes.
The pronoun they is used without its antecedent, so the meaning of the sentence is unclear.
This problem can be fixed by replacing the pronoun with its missing antecedent.
The advertisements say that this nail polish dries in less than five minutes.
1580.solution:
The first answer choice contains a vague pronoun reference. The pronoun them could refer to the new employees or their intake forms.
The second answer choice shows a possible correction for the vague pronoun reference. Them has been replaced with the forms.
Mr. Warren wanted the new employees to fill out their intake forms, but he couldn't find the forms.

1581.question: What can Connor and Vicky trade to each get what they want?
choices: Connor can trade his tomatoes for Vicky's sandwich.
Vicky can trade her broccoli for Connor's oranges.
Vicky can trade her almonds for Connor's tomatoes.
Connor can trade his tomatoes for Vicky's broccoli.
1581.hint:
Trade happens when people agree to exchange goods and services. People give up something to get something else. Sometimes people barter, or directly exchange one good or service for another.
Connor and Vicky open their lunch boxes in the school cafeteria. Both of them could be happier with their lunches. Connor wanted broccoli in his lunch and Vicky was hoping for tomatoes. Look at the images of their lunches. Then answer the question below.
1581.subject: social science
1581.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will examine the image to identify the items in Connor's and Vicky's lunches. I'll focus specifically on the items that Connor and Vicky want to trade. Then, I will match these items with the options given to determine the correct trade that satisfies both Connor and Vicky.

The image shows two lunchboxes. In Connor's lunch, there is a sandwich, cherry tomatoes, orange slices, and a bottle of water. In Vicky's lunch, there is a sandwich, broccoli, carrot sticks, almonds, blueberries, strawberries, and a bottle of water.
1581.solution:
The image content reveals that Connor has tomatoes and Vicky has broccoli. According to the context, Connor is interested in trading to get broccoli, and Vicky is interested in trading to get tomatoes. Examining the options:
(A) Involves trading tomatoes for a sandwich, which is unrelated to their desires.
(B) Involves trading broccoli for oranges, which doesn't satisfy their wants.
(C) Involves trading almonds for tomatoes, which doesn’t fulfill their preferences.
(D) Proposes trading tomatoes for broccoli, which directly satisfies both Connor's and Vicky's wants.
Therefore, the trade described in option D would allow both to get what they want: Connor receives broccoli, and Vicky receives tomatoes.

1582.question: Which country is highlighted?
1582.subject: social science
1582.skill: Identify and select countries of Oceania

1583.question: Compare the average kinetic energies of the particles in each sample. Which sample has the higher temperature?
choices: neither; the samples have the same temperature
1583.hint: The diagrams below show two pure samples of gas in identical closed, rigid containers. Each colored ball represents one gas particle. Both samples have the same number of particles.
1583.subject: natural science
1583.skill: Identify how particle motion affects temperature and pressure
1583.lecture:
The temperature of a substance depends on the average kinetic energy of the particles in the substance. The higher the average kinetic energy of the particles, the higher the temperature of the substance.
The kinetic energy of a particle is determined by its mass and speed. For a pure substance, the greater the mass of each particle in the substance and the higher the average speed of the particles, the higher their average kinetic energy.
1583.solution:
Each particle in the two samples has the same mass, and the particles in both samples have the same average speed. So, the particles in both samples have the same average kinetic energy.
Because the particles in both samples have the same average kinetic energy, the samples must have the same temperature.

1584.question: Which text uses the word disinterested in its traditional sense?
choices: As a teacher of American history, Mr. Gordon tries to remain disinterested when discussing controversial issues, giving equal attention and consideration to each major viewpoint.
As an experienced teacher of American history, Mr. Gordon believes that playing history-based trivia games will revive even the most disinterested of students.
1584.subject: language science
1584.skill: Explore words with new or contested usages
1584.lecture:
Words change in meaning when speakers begin using them in new ways. For example, the word peruse once only meant to examine in detail, but it's now also commonly used to mean to look through in a casual manner.
When a word changes in meaning, its correct usage is often debated. Although a newer sense of the word may be more commonly used, many people consider a word's traditional definition to be the correct usage. Being able to distinguish the different uses of a word can help you use it appropriately for different audiences.
Britney perused her notes, carefully preparing for her exam.
The traditional usage above is considered more standard.
David perused the magazine, absentmindedly flipping through the pages.
The nontraditional usage above is now commonly used, but traditional style guides generally advise against it.
1584.solution:
The first text uses disinterested in its traditional sense: unbiased or impartial.
As a teacher of American history, Mr. Gordon tries to remain disinterested when discussing controversial issues, giving equal attention and consideration to each major viewpoint.
The second text uses disinterested in its nontraditional sense: uninterested or indifferent.
As an experienced teacher of American history, Mr. Gordon believes that playing history-based trivia games will revive even the most disinterested of students.
Most style guides recommend to use the traditional sense of the word disinterested because it is considered more standard.

1585.question: Select the reptile below.
1585.hint: Reptiles have scaly, waterproof skin. Most reptiles live on land. A tortoise is an example of a reptile.
1585.subject: natural science
1585.skill: Identify mammals, birds, fish, reptiles, and amphibians
1585.lecture:
Birds, mammals, fish, reptiles, and amphibians are groups of animals. The animals in each group have traits in common.
Scientists sort animals into groups based on traits they have in common. This process is called classification.
1585.solution:
A coral snake is a reptile. It has scaly, waterproof skin.
A giraffe is a mammal. It has hair and feeds its young milk.

1586.question: Which of these states is farthest south?
1586.subject: social science
1586.lecture:
Maps have four cardinal directions, or main directions. Those directions are north, south, east, and west.
A compass rose is a set of arrows that point to the cardinal directions. A compass rose usually shows only the first letter of each cardinal direction.
The north arrow points to the North Pole. On most maps, north is at the top of the map.
1586.solution: To find the answer, look at the compass rose. Look at which way the south arrow is pointing. Missouri is farthest south.

1587.question: Select the vertebrate.
1587.hint: Hint: Mammals, birds, fish, reptiles, and amphibians are vertebrates.
1587.subject: natural science
1587.lecture:
Vertebrates and invertebrates are both groups of animals.
A vertebrate has a backbone. The backbone is made of many bones in an animal's back. A vertebrate's backbone helps connect the different parts of its body. In the drawings below, each vertebrate's backbone is colored orange.
An invertebrate does not have a backbone. In fact, invertebrates do not have any bones! Some invertebrates have a hard outer cover on their body. Other invertebrates have a soft body.
1587.solution:
A pig is a mammal. Like other mammals, a pig is a vertebrate. It has a backbone.
A grasshopper is an insect. Like other insects, a grasshopper is an invertebrate. It does not have a backbone. It has a hard outer cover.

1588.question:
Which tense does the sentence use?
The president of the company announces the plan.
1588.subject: language science
1588.skill: Is the sentence in the past, present, or future tense?
1588.lecture:
Present tense verbs tell you about something that is happening now.
Most present-tense verbs are regular. They have no ending, or they end in -s or -es.
Two verbs are irregular in the present tense, to be and to have. You must remember their forms.
Past tense verbs tell you about something that has already happened.
Most past-tense verbs are regular. They end in -ed.
Some verbs are irregular in the past tense. You must remember their past-tense forms.
Future tense verbs tell you about something that is going to happen.
All future-tense verbs use the word will.
Present | Past | Future
walk, walks | walked | will walk
go, goes | went | will go
1588.solution: The sentence is in present tense. You can tell because it uses a present-tense verb, announces. The verb ends in -s and tells you about something that is true or happening now.

1589.question: Which three months have the same average precipitation?
1589.hint: Use the graph to answer the question below.
1589.subject: natural science
1589.skill: Use climate data to make predictions
1589.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will examine the bar graph to identify which three months have the same average precipitation by looking for bars of equal height. I will compare the heights visually to determine the correct option.

The image is a bar graph showing the average precipitation in inches for each month in Chicago, Illinois. Each month's precipitation is represented by a colored bar, with the height of the bar indicating the precipitation level.
1589.solution:
First, I will look at each month's bar on the graph to determine its height. I will check for months with identical bar heights, indicating the same average precipitation. Upon review: 
- January and February have bars slightly below 2 inches.
- June and July have similar bars, around 3.5 inches.
- August has a noticeably higher bar, over 4 inches.
- September, October, and November all have bars just over 3 inches.
Therefore, the months with equal average precipitation are September, October, and November.

1590.question: Which of these cities is marked on the map?
1590.subject: social science
1590.solution: The city is Atlanta, Georgia. Oklahoma City, Nashville, and Miami are marked with gray circles on the map below.

1591.question: Assume all other forces on the train are balanced. Which statement describes the forces on the train?
choices: The forces are unbalanced, so there is a net force on the train.
The forces are balanced, so there is no net force on the train.
1591.hint: A train is sitting on a magnetic track. Earth's gravity is pulling down on the train with a force of 200,000N. The magnetic track is pushing up on the train with a force of 200,000N.
1591.subject: natural science
1591.lecture:
A force is a push or a pull that acts on an object. Every force has a direction and a magnitude, or strength. If two forces act on an object in opposite directions, the forces are called opposing forces.
When opposing forces have the same magnitude, they are balanced. If all the forces on an object are balanced, there is no net force on the object.
When opposing forces have different magnitudes, the forces are unbalanced. If any forces on an object are unbalanced, there is a net force on the object.
1591.solution:
To determine if there is a net force on the train, look at the forces:
Earth's gravity is pulling the train down with a force of 200,000 N.
The magnetic track is pushing the train up with a force of 200,000 N.
The forces are in opposite directions, and the forces have the same magnitude: 200,000 N. This means that the forces are balanced, so there is no net force on the train.

1592.question:
What does the metaphor in this text suggest?
When Zeke lost his job, he was devastated. The only light in the sea of darkness was the prospect of pursuing a new career.
choices: Zeke felt in the dark about what to do after losing his job.
There was a benefit to Zeke's job loss.
1592.subject: language science
1592.lecture:
Figures of speech are words or phrases that use language in a nonliteral or unusual way. They can make writing more expressive.
A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.
The snow formed a blanket over the town.
1592.solution:
The text uses a metaphor, comparing two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.
The metaphor the only light in the sea of darkness was the prospect of pursuing a new career suggests that there was a benefit to Zeke's job loss. A light would be beneficial in helping someone escape a dark, difficult-to-navigate situation. Similarly, Zeke's new career was beneficial in helping him escape the emotionally difficult experience of losing his job.

1593.question: What is the temperature of a hot day in the desert?
1593.subject: natural science
1593.lecture:
Measurements are written with both a number and a unit. The unit comes after the number. The unit shows what the number means.
Temperature can be written with units of degrees Fahrenheit (°F) or Celsius (°C). Use the list below to compare the two units.
212°F | Water boils | 100°C
98.6°F | Body temperature | 37°C
68°F | Room temperature | 20°C
32°F | Water freezes | 0°C
1593.solution:
The better estimate for the temperature of a hot day in the desert is 47°C.
47°F is too cold.

1594.question: Think about the magnetic force between the magnets in each pair. Which of the following statements is true?
choices: The magnetic force is weaker in Pair 1.
The magnetic force is weaker in Pair 2.
The strength of the magnetic force is the same in both pairs.
1594.hint: The images below show two pairs of magnets. The magnets in different pairs do not affect each other. All the magnets shown are made of the same material.
1594.subject: natural science
1594.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will analyze the given image of two pairs of magnets to compare the magnetic forces based on their orientations and distance. I'll follow a step-by-step process to determine if the forces are different or the same.

The image shows two pairs of magnets labeled as Pair 1 and Pair 2. Each pair has two magnets arranged with their respective poles labeled 'N' for North and 'S' for South. In Pair 1, the N pole of one magnet is close to the S pole of the other magnet. In Pair 2, the S pole of one magnet is close to the N pole of the other magnet. The distance between the magnets in both pairs is the same, labeled as 2 inches.
1594.solution: Magnetic force depends on the strength of the magnets and the distance between them. When opposite poles are facing each other (N to S), the magnets attract each other. Since the distance between the magnets in both pairs is the same, and the material of the magnets is consistent, the strength of the magnetic force will solely depend on the orientation. In both pairs, the opposite poles are facing each other, leading to an attractive force. Therefore, despite the change in sequence, the magnetic force's magnitude remains unaffected because the orientation from N to S in both cases is an attraction, resulting in equal magnetic forces.

1595.question: Which soccer ball has a lower temperature?
choices: the soccer ball with more thermal energy
the soccer ball with less thermal energy
1595.hint: Two soccer balls are identical except for their thermal energies.
1595.subject: natural science
1595.skill: How are temperature and mass related to thermal energy?
1595.lecture:
Matter is made of tiny particles called atoms. Atoms are always moving.
The energy of moving atoms is called thermal energy. The total amount of thermal energy in matter depends on three things: the type of matter, the amount of matter, and how fast the atoms are moving.
Temperature measures how hot or cold matter is. If the atoms in matter slow down, the temperature goes down. The matter now has both less thermal energy and a lower temperature.
What happens if the amount of matter changes? A 2-kilogram brick at 70°F has twice as much thermal energy as a 1-kilogram brick at 70°F. The two bricks have the same temperature, but the larger brick has twice as many atoms. So, it has twice as much thermal energy.
1595.solution: The two soccer balls are made of the same material and have the same mass. So, the soccer ball with less thermal energy has a lower temperature.

1596.question: Compare the motion of three motorboats. Which motorboat was moving at the highest speed?
choices: a motorboat that moved 180kilometers east in 5hours
a motorboat that moved 360kilometers south in 5hours
a motorboat that moved 90kilometers east in 5hours
1596.subject: natural science
1596.skill: Compare the speeds of moving objects
1596.lecture:
An object's speed tells you how fast the object is moving. Speed depends on both distance and time.
Distance tells you how far the object has moved. One unit used to measure distance is the kilometer.
Time tells you how long the object has spent moving. One unit used to measure time is the hour.
Think about objects moving for the same amount of time. The object that is moving the fastest will go the farthest distance in that time. It is moving at the highest speed.
1596.solution:
Look at the distance each motorboat moved and the time it took to move that distance. The direction each motorboat moved does not affect its speed.
Notice that each motorboat moved for 5 hours. The motorboat that moved 360 kilometers moved the farthest distance in that time. So, that motorboat must have moved at the highest speed.

1597.question: Which of these oceans does the prime meridian intersect?
1597.subject: social science
1597.skill: Use lines of latitude and longitude
1597.lecture:
To determine which ocean the prime meridian intersects, I will locate the prime meridian on the map and observe the oceans it crosses. I'll then use this information to identify the correct option from the given choices.

The image shows a world map with continents and oceans labeled. The map also displays lines of latitude and longitude, with the prime meridian marked as the line at 0° longitude. It runs from the North Pole through Europe and Africa to the South Pole.
1597.solution: To find which ocean the prime meridian intersects, start by identifying the line at 0° longitude on the map. This line passes through the following relevant regions: it begins at the North Pole, crosses the Arctic Ocean, continues through Europe and Africa, and concludes at the South Pole. Observing these intersections, only the Arctic Ocean is crossed by the prime meridian. The Indian and Pacific Oceans are not intersected by the prime meridian, as it runs through different geographical areas.

1598.question: What information supports the conclusion that John inherited this trait?
choices: John wears glasses and so do his sisters.
John's friend also has hazel eyes.
John's biological father wears contacts in his hazel eyes.
1598.hint:
Read the description of a trait.
John has hazel eyes.
1598.subject: natural science
1598.skill: Inherited and acquired traits: use evidence to support a statement
1598.lecture:
Organisms, including people, have both inherited and acquired traits. Inherited and acquired traits are gained in different ways.
Inherited traits are passed down from biological parents to their offspring through genes. Genes are pieces of hereditary material that contain the instructions that affect inherited traits. Offspring receive their genes, and therefore gain their inherited traits, from their biological parents. Inherited traits do not need to be learned.
Acquired traits are gained during a person's life. Some acquired traits, such as riding a bicycle, are gained by learning. Other acquired traits, such as scars, are caused by the environment. Parents do not pass acquired traits down to their offspring.

1599.question:
What do these two changes have in common?
a copper statue turning green
baking an apple pie
1599.subject: natural science
1599.lecture:
Chemical changes and physical changes are two common ways matter can change.
In a chemical change, the type of matter changes. The types of matter before and after a chemical change are always different.
Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example, burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. When paper gets hot enough, it re­acts with oxygen in the air and burns. The paper and oxygen change into ash and smoke.
In a physical change, the type of matter stays the same. The types of matter before and after a physical change are always the same.
A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example, ice melting is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Ice and liquid water are made of the same type of matter: water.
The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So, the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change.
1599.solution:
Step 1: Think about each change.
A copper statue turning green is a chemical change. The copper reacts with oxygen in the air. This reaction forms a different type of matter called copper oxide. The copper oxide is green.
Baking an apple pie is a chemical change. The type of matter in the pie changes when it is baked. The crust turns brown, and the apples become soft.
Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. They are not physical changes.
Both are chemical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. The type of matter before and after each change is different.
Both are caused by heating.
Baking is caused by heating. But a copper statue turning green is not.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling.

1600.question:
What kind of sentence is this?
No one lives at the base of the volcano.
1600.subject: language science
1600.skill: Is the sentence declarative, interrogative, imperative, or exclamatory?
1600.lecture:
There are four kinds of sentences.
A declarative sentence is a statement. It tells about something. A declarative sentence always ends with a period.
I have an older brother and a younger sister.
An interrogative sentence is a question. It asks something. An interrogative sentence always ends with a question mark.
How tall are you?
An imperative sentence is a command. It makes a request or tells someone to do something. An imperative sentence usually ends with a period. If the command shows strong feeling, it ends with an exclamation point.
Read the first chapter by next week.
Look out for that car!
An exclamatory sentence is like a statement, but it shows surprise or strong feeling. An exclamatory sentence always ends with an exclamation point.
Some whales are over ninety feet long!
I can't wait until tomorrow!
1600.solution: The sentence tells about something, and it ends with a period. It is a declarative sentence.

1601.question: Is grape juice a solid, a liquid, or a gas?
1601.subject: natural science
1601.skill: Classify matter as solid, liquid, or gas
1601.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will first describe the image, focusing on the visual elements pertinent to the states of matter. Then, I will reason through the characteristics of states of matter and apply them to the image content. Finally, I'll conclude with the standard correct answer format.

The image depicts a glass that is filled with a red liquid, likely grape juice. The red liquid takes the shape of the glass and has a consistent appearance throughout.
1601.solution: The image shows a red substance inside a glass container. Since the substance conforms to the shape of the container, it is characteristic of a liquid. Liquids have a definite volume but take the shape of their container, unlike solids, which have a definite shape, or gases, which have neither a definite volume nor shape. Therefore, based on the observation of the substance taking the container's shape but maintaining a consistent volume, it is evident that the substance is in a liquid state.

1602.question: What can Harper and Adriana trade to each get what they want?
choices: Harper can trade her tomatoes for Adriana's broccoli.
Adriana can trade her broccoli for Harper's oranges.
Adriana can trade her almonds for Harper's tomatoes.
Harper can trade her tomatoes for Adriana's carrots.
1602.hint:
Trade happens when people agree to exchange goods and services. People give up something to get something else. Sometimes people barter, or directly exchange one good or service for another.
Harper and Adriana open their lunch boxes in the school cafeteria. Neither Harper nor Adriana got everything that they wanted. The table below shows which items they each wanted:

Look at the images of their lunches. Then answer the question below.
Harper's lunch Adriana's lunch
1602.subject: social science
1602.solution:
Look at the table and images.
Harper wants broccoli. Adriana wants tomatoes. They can trade tomatoes for broccoli to both get what they want. Trading other things would not help both people get more items they want.

1603.question: Select the organism in the same species as the blue jay.
1603.hint: This organism is a blue jay. Its scientific name is Cyanocitta cristata.
1603.subject: natural science
1603.skill: Use scientific names to classify organisms
1603.lecture:
I will analyze the scientific names of the organisms provided in the options and compare them to the image's blue jay to determine which option shares the same species.

The image shows a blue jay perched on a flowering branch. The bird has a characteristic blue color with a distinctive crest on its head, identifying its species as Cyanocitta cristata.
1603.solution:
To determine the organism in the same species as the blue jay, we need to look at the scientific names. The scientific name of the blue jay in the image is Cyanocitta cristata. An organism in the same species must have an identical scientific name. 

Option (A) Pelecanus occidentalis does not match this name, so it is not the correct choice. 

Option (B) Cyanocitta stelleri shares the same genus but not the same species, so it cannot be the answer. 

Option (C) Cyanocitta cristata matches the scientific name of the blue jay exactly, indicating it belongs to the same species. 

Thus, the organism in the same species as the blue jay is Cyanocitta cristata.

1604.question: What is the name of the colony shown?
1604.subject: social science
1604.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will examine the image to determine which colony is highlighted in a darker color. Then, I will use my knowledge to match it with the given options and historical context to identify the correct answer.

The image displays a map of the eastern United States, highlighting a group of colonies in light green with one colony in dark green. The colony shown in dark green is located in the northeastern region of the map, corresponding to current-day New England.
1604.solution:
Looking at the image, the colony highlighted in dark green is located in the northeastern part of the map. In the context of American colonial history, the colony that would be located in this position is New Hampshire. Analyzing the options provided:

- (A) Ohio: Located in the Midwest, not applicable.
- (B) Michigan: Also in the Midwest, not applicable.
- (C) West Virginia: Further south and west, not applicable.
- (D) New Hampshire: Located in New England, which matches the highlighted region.

The colony shown is indeed New Hampshire based on its location on the map and historical context.

1605.question: Which correctly shows the title of a poem?

The title of a poem, song, article, or short story should be in quotation marks.
"You Are My Sunshine"
1605.solution:
A poem should be in quotation marks.
The correct title is "The Mountain and the Squirrel."

1606.question:
Would you find the word beauty on a dictionary page with the following guide words?
blame - bunk
1606.subject: language science
1606.lecture:
Guide words appear on each page of a dictionary. They tell you the first word and last word on the page. The other words on the page come between the guide words in alphabetical order.
To put words in alphabetical order, put them in order by their first letters. If the first letters are the same, look at the second letters. If the second letters are the same, look at the third letters, and so on.
If one word is shorter, and there are no more letters to compare, then the shorter word comes first in alphabetical order.
1606.solution:
Put the words in alphabetical order.
Since beauty is not between the guide words blame - bunk, it would not be found on that page.

1607.question:
Complete the statement.
Phosphine is ().
1607.hint: Phosphine is a poisonous gas that some farmers use to kill insects. The chemical formula for phosphine is PH3.
1607.subject: natural science
1607.skill: Classify elementary substances and compounds using chemical formulas
1607.lecture:
Every substance around you is made of one or more chemical elements, or types of atoms. Substances that are made of only one chemical element are elementary substances. Substances that are made of two or more chemical elements bonded together are compounds.
Every chemical element is represented by its own symbol. For some elements, the symbol is one capital letter. For other elements, the symbol is one capital letter and one lowercase letter. For example, the symbol for the element fluorine is F, and the symbol for the element beryllium is Be.
The symbol for each element in a substance is shown in the substance's chemical formula.
An elementary substance is represented by a chemical formula that contains only one symbol.
The symbol may be followed by a subscript. A subscript is text that is smaller and placed lower than the normal line of text. A subscript is included when the atoms in the elementary substance are bonded to form molecules. The subscript tells you the number of atoms in each molecule.
For example, the chemical formula for the elementary substance oxygen is O2. The formula has a subscript of 2. This subscript tells you that there are two atoms in the molecule represented by this chemical formula.
The chemical element represented by the symbol O is also called oxygen. So, the formula O2 tells you that each molecule of O2 contains two oxygen atoms.
A compound is represented by a chemical formula that contains multiple symbols.
For example, in the compound beryllium fluoride, there is one beryllium atom for every two fluorine atoms. This combination is shown in the compound's chemical formula, BeF2. In the formula, the symbol Be represents one beryllium atom. The symbol F followed by the subscript 2 represents two fluorine atoms.
1607.solution:
You can tell whether phosphine is an elementary substance or a compound by counting the number of symbols in its chemical formula. A symbol contains either one capital letter or a capital letter followed by one or two lowercase letters.
The chemical formula for phosphine is PH3. This formula contains two symbols: P for phosphorus and H for hydrogen. So, the formula tells you that phosphine is made of two chemical elements bonded together.
Substances made of two or more chemical elements bonded together are compounds. So, phosphine is a compound.

1608.question: Which is a run-on sentence?
choices: Vocal cords in your throat help you make sounds.
Jasper won the school costume contest, his mom felt proud.
1608.subject: language science
1608.skill: Is it a complete sentence, a fragment, or a run-on?
1608.lecture:
A sentence is a group of words that forms a complete thought. It has both a subject and a verb.
My friends walk along the path.
A sentence fragment is a group of words that does not express a complete thought. It is usually missing a subject or a verb.
Knows the answer.
This is a sentence fragment. It is missing a subject.
Who knows the answer? She knows the answer.
The bright red car.
This is a sentence fragment. It is missing a verb.
What did the bright red car do? The bright red car stopped.
A run-on sentence is made up of two sentences that are joined without end punctuation or with just a comma.
I knocked on the door it opened.
It started raining, we ran inside.
To fix a run-on sentence, separate it into two sentences. Add end punctuation after the first sentence, and capitalize the second sentence.
I knocked on the door. It opened.
It started raining. We ran inside.
You can also fix a run-on sentence by rewriting it as a compound sentence. A compound sentence is two sentences joined by a comma and a conjunction such as and, but, or, or so.
I knocked on the door, and it opened.
It started raining, so we ran inside.
1608.solution: Jasper won the school costume contest, his mom felt proud is a run-on sentence. It has two sentences that are joined by just a comma: Jasper won the school costume contest and His mom felt proud.

1609.question: What can Mackenzie and Zane trade to each get what they want?
choices: Mackenzie can trade her tomatoes for Zane's broccoli.
Zane can trade his broccoli for Mackenzie's oranges.
Zane can trade his almonds for Mackenzie's tomatoes.
Mackenzie can trade her tomatoes for Zane's sandwich.
1609.hint:
Trade happens when people agree to exchange goods and services. People give up something to get something else. Sometimes people barter, or directly exchange one good or service for another.
Mackenzie and Zane open their lunch boxes in the school cafeteria. Both of them could be happier with their lunches. Mackenzie wanted broccoli in her lunch and Zane was hoping for tomatoes. Look at the images of their lunches. Then answer the question below.
1609.subject: social science
1609.lecture:
I will compare Mackenzie’s and Zane’s lunches to identify the items they wish to trade. Then, I will match the items that they desire with those available for trade, considering the options provided.

Mackenzie’s lunch includes a sandwich, tomatoes, and oranges, along with a water bottle. Zane’s lunch contains a sandwich, broccoli, carrots, almonds, blueberries, strawberries, and a water bottle.
1609.solution: According to the context, Mackenzie wanted broccoli, and Zane was hoping for tomatoes. Mackenzie has tomatoes in her lunch, and Zane has broccoli. Therefore, Mackenzie can give her tomatoes to Zane, and he can give his broccoli to Mackenzie. Checking the options provided: Option (A) states that Mackenzie can trade her tomatoes for Zane's broccoli, which aligns with their desires. Other options do not satisfy the requirement for both to receive what they want.

1610.question: Which letter to the editor is more formal?
choices: I'm writing because I'm fed up about our library not staying open like it used to.
I am writing to express my dissatisfaction with the library's reduced hours.
1610.subject: language science
1610.lecture:
Informal writing is typically used in casual situations or when communicating with someone you know well. Informal language often expresses familiarity and tends to sound more like speech. It uses more conversational language, such as slang, idioms, abbreviations, imprecise language, and contractions.
Formal writing is typically used in academic and business writing or when writing directly to an authority figure. It tends to be more courteous and impersonal, avoiding overly familiar or conversational language.
Compare the following sentences.
Informal: Yeah, ostriches can't fly, but I think they're awesome.
More formal: Ostriches may be flightless, but they're remarkable runners.
Most formal: Though flightless, ostriches are remarkable runners.
1610.solution: The second letter to the editor is more formal. It uses more elevated language (writing to express my dissatisfaction, reduced hours). The other letter to the editor uses contractions (I'm) and slang (fed up).

1611.question: Which of these continents does the equator intersect?
1611.subject: social science
1611.skill: Use lines of latitude and longitude
1611.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will examine the map to identify which continents the equator crosses. I will use the labels and the grid lines of latitude to determine the intersection with continents. This will allow me to select the correct answer from the options provided.

The image is a world map highlighting continents in green and oceans in blue. Latitude and longitude lines are drawn over the map, with the equator marked at 0° latitude. Continents shown include North America, South America, Europe, Africa, Asia, Australia, and Antarctica.
1611.solution:
The equator is the horizontal line marked at 0° latitude on the map. I need to see which continents it intersects. On observing the map:

- The equator clearly crosses through the middle of Africa, a large portion of South America, and the southern part of Asia.
  
- I see that Europe and North America are situated well north of the equator and are not intersected by it.

- Asia extends across a large area, and the equator crosses its southern part.

According to the options provided, I need to check among Europe, Asia, and North America. From my observation, the equator intersects Asia. Therefore, the answer is B.

1612.question:
Which word would you find on a dictionary page with the following guide words?
slate - strong
1612.subject: language science
1612.lecture:
Guide words appear on each page of a dictionary. They tell you the first word and last word on the page. The other words on the page come between the guide words in alphabetical order.
To put words in alphabetical order, put them in order by their first letters. If the first letters are the same, look at the second letters. If the second letters are the same, look at the third letters, and so on.
If one word is shorter, and there are no more letters to compare, then the shorter word comes first in alphabetical order.
1612.solution:
Put the words in alphabetical order.
Since smile is between the guide words slate - strong, it would be found on that page.

1613.question: Which of these states is farthest south?
1613.subject: social science
1613.lecture:
I will determine which of the labeled states is farthest south using the compass rose on the map. I will identify their positions and compare them in relation to the south direction.

The image is a map of the United States with four states labeled: Idaho, Minnesota, Nebraska, and New Hampshire. A compass rose indicating the cardinal directions (N, S, E, W) is visible at the bottom right corner.
1613.solution: To find which state is farthest south, I will refer to the compass rose indicating south. Generally, maps are oriented with north at the top, so south will be at the bottom. I will locate each labeled state on the map: Nebraska is in the central United States, Idaho is to the northwest, Minnesota is north and slightly to the east of Nebraska, and New Hampshire is in the far northeast. Comparing their latitudinal positions, Nebraska is lower on the map than Minnesota, Idaho, and New Hampshire, indicating it is the farthest south.

1614.question: Identify the question that Patty's experiment can best answer.
choices: Do more tomato seedlings grow when they are planted in soil with fertilizer compared to soil without fertilizer?
Does the humidity level where tomato seeds are planted affect the number of tomato seedlings that grow?
1614.hint:
The passage below describes an experiment. Read the passage and then follow the instructions below.

Patty planted 25 tomato seeds one-half inch below the soil surface in each of six pots. Patty added an equal amount of fertilizer to three of the six pots. She placed the pots in a plant growth chamber where all the seeds experienced the same temperature, amount of light, and humidity level. After two weeks, Patty counted the number of seedlings that grew in each pot. She compared the number of seedlings in the pots with fertilizer to the number of seedlings in the pots without fertilizer.
Figure: tomato seedlings growing in soil.
1614.subject: natural science
1614.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will identify the variables tested and measured in Patty's tomato seedling experiment by relating these to the given answer options. This will involve analyzing the experiment's setup and results based on what was specifically varied and observed.

The image shows young seedlings emerging from the soil. This visual represents the outcome of planting seeds and monitoring their growth, aligning with Patty's experiment.
1614.solution: In Patty's experiment, the variable she tested was the presence of fertilizer in the soil. She added fertilizer to half of the pots and kept the other half without it. The condition kept constant across all pots included temperature, light, and humidity, which indicates that these factors are not part of the test. The measured outcome was the number of seedlings that sprouted in each pot after two weeks, comparing those with fertilizer to those without. Therefore, Patty's experiment specifically evaluated the impact of fertilizer on the number of tomato seedlings, making Option (A) the matching query.

1615.question: Which organ takes in oxygen from the air?
1615.subject: natural science

1616.question: Which of the following fossils is older? Select the more likely answer.
1616.hint: This diagram shows fossils in an undisturbed sedimentary rock sequence.
1616.subject: natural science
1616.skill: Compare ages of fossils in a rock sequence
1616.lecture:
A fossil is the preserved evidence of an ancient organism. Some fossils are formed from body parts such as bones or shells. Other fossils, such as footprints or burrows, are formed from traces of an organism's activities.
Fossils are typically found in sedimentary rocks. Sedimentary rocks usually form in layers. Over time, new layers are added on top of old layers in a series called a rock sequence. The layers in an undisturbed rock sequence are in the same order as when they formed. So, the deeper layers are older than the shallower layers.
The relative ages of fossils can be determined from their positions in an undisturbed rock sequence. Older fossils are usually in deeper layers, and younger fossils are usually in shallower layers.
1616.solution:
Look again at the fossils in the rock sequence diagram.
Compare the positions of these fossils to determine which one is older:
The wood fossil is in a deeper layer in the rock sequence than the ginkgo leaf fossil. So, the wood fossil is most likely older than the ginkgo leaf fossil.

1617.question:
Which figure of speech is used in this text?
It's an open secret that Ryan is writing a book based on his experiences living in Singapore. He never talks about it, but almost all his friends know.
1617.subject: language science
1617.skill: Classify the figure of speech: euphemism, hyperbole, oxymoron, paradox
1617.lecture:
Figures of speech are words or phrases that use language in a nonliteral or unusual way. They can make writing more expressive.
A euphemism is a polite or indirect expression that is used to de-emphasize an unpleasant topic.
The head of Human Resources would never refer to firing people, only to laying them off.
Hyperbole is an obvious exaggeration that is not meant to be taken literally.
I ate so much that I think I might explode!
An oxymoron is a joining of two seemingly contradictory terms.
Some reviewers are calling this book a new classic.
A paradox is a statement that might at first appear to be contradictory, but that may in fact contain some truth.
Always expect the unexpected.
1617.solution:
The text uses an oxymoron, a joining of two seemingly contradictory terms.
Open secret is a contradiction, because open describes something that is freely or publicly known, and a secret is hidden.

1618.question: Which closing is correct for a letter?
1618.subject: language science

Dear Aunt Sue,

thank you for the birthday gift. I could not have

of you.

1618.solution:
The second closing is correct:
Its first word is capitalized, and it ends with a comma.

Dear Aunt Sue,

1620.question: Compare the average kinetic energies of the particles in each sample. Which sample has the higher temperature?
choices: neither; the samples have the same temperature
1620.hint: The diagrams below show two pure samples of gas in identical closed, rigid containers. Each colored ball represents one gas particle. Both samples have the same number of particles.
1620.subject: natural science
1620.skill: Identify how particle motion affects temperature and pressure
1620.lecture:
To solve this problem, I will analyze the kinetic energies of particles in both samples based on their mass and speed, as depicted in the image. I will compare these energies to determine which sample has the higher temperature, since the temperature correlates with average kinetic energy.

The image shows two samples of gas in identical closed, rigid containers. Sample A contains green particles with a mass of 44 u and an average speed of 1,200 m/s. Sample B contains blue particles with a mass of 40 u and an average speed of 1,100 m/s. Both samples have the same number of particles.
1620.solution:
The kinetic energy of a particle is calculated using the formula \( KE = \frac{1}{2} mv^2 \), where \( m \) is the mass and \( v \) is the velocity of the particle. For temperature comparison, focus on the average kinetic energy, which is primarily influenced by the mass and speed of particles.

In Sample A, each particle has a mass of 44 u and an average speed of 1,200 m/s. In Sample B, each particle has a mass of 40 u and an average speed of 1,100 m/s. Kinetic energy is directly proportional to both the mass and the square of the speed.

1. The particles in Sample A have more mass (44 u) than those in Sample B (40 u).
2. The average speed of particles in Sample A (1,200 m/s) is also greater than that in Sample B (1,100 m/s).

Both higher mass and greater speed contribute to higher kinetic energy. Therefore, Sample A, with both greater mass and speed, will have a higher average kinetic energy compared to Sample B. Since temperature is dependent on average kinetic energy, Sample A must have a higher temperature.

1621.question:
What do these two changes have in common?
baking cookies
water evaporating from a puddle
1621.subject: natural science
1621.lecture:
Chemical changes and physical changes are two common ways matter can change.
In a chemical change, the type of matter changes. The types of matter before and after a chemical change are always different.
Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example, burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. When paper gets hot enough, it re­acts with oxygen in the air and burns. The paper and oxygen change into ash and smoke.
In a physical change, the type of matter stays the same. The types of matter before and after a physical change are always the same.
A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example, ice melting is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Ice and liquid water are made of the same type of matter: water.
The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So, the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change.
1621.solution:
Step 1: Think about each change.
Baking cookies is a chemical change. Cookies are made from cookie dough. Baking turns the cookie dough into cookies. The cookies are a different type of matter than the dough.
Water evaporating from a puddle is a change of state. So, it is a physical change. The liquid changes into a gas, but a different type of matter is not formed.
Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Water evaporating is a physical change. But baking cookies is not.
Both are chemical changes.
Baking cookies is a chemical change. But water evaporating from a puddle is not.
Both are caused by heating.
Both changes are caused by heating.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling.

1622.question: Select the phase of the Moon shown in the model.
1622.hint: The model below shows the Moon at one position in its orbit around Earth. The white half of the Moon shows the part that is lit up by the Sun.
1622.subject: natural science
1622.lecture:
Although the Moon appears to shine, it does not give off light. Instead, we can see the Moon because it is lit up by the Sun. The part of the Moon that is both lit up by the Sun and facing Earth is called the Moon's phase.
The Moon orbits, or goes around, Earth. As it does, the Moon's phase changes. The model below shows the Moon's phase at eight positions in its orbit. The smaller moons closer to Earth show where sunlight hits the Moon. The larger moons farther from Earth show how the Moon will look during that phase.
To use the model, first pick one of the eight positions. Then, imagine standing on Earth and looking up at the Moon. Use the dotted white lines in the model to guide you. The picture of the Moon shows its phase for that position. If you are in the Southern Hemisphere, the Moon will appear flipped, left to right.

1623.question: What is the mass of a school bus?
1623.subject: natural science
1623.lecture:
Measurements are written with both a number and a unit. The unit comes after the number. The unit shows what the number means.
Mass is a measurement of how much matter something contains.
There are many different units of mass. When you are using customary units, mass may be written with units of ounces, pounds, or tons.
There are 16 ounces in 1 pound and 2,000 pounds in 1 ton.
So, 1 ounce is less than 1 pound and much less than 1 ton.
A slice of bread has a mass of about 1 ounce, while a can of beans has a mass of about 1 pound. A small car has a mass of about 1 ton.
1623.solution:
The best estimate for the mass of a school bus is 15 tons.
15 ounces and 15 pounds are both too light.

1624.question: Is rubber a mineral?
1624.hint:
Rubber has the following properties:
human-made
not a pure substance
solid
no fixed crystal structure
1624.subject: natural science
1624.lecture:
I will assess whether rubber is a mineral by comparing its properties to those that define a mineral, following a structured approach to reach an accurate conclusion.

The image shows a rubber band, which is an elastic loop made from rubber, a flexible and durable material.
1624.solution:
To determine if rubber is a mineral, I will compare its properties to the criteria of minerals:
1. A mineral is a solid: Rubber is solid.
2. A mineral is formed in nature: Rubber is human-made, not naturally occurring.
3. A mineral is not made by organisms: Rubber is manufactured by humans, who are organisms.
4. A mineral is a pure substance: Rubber is not a pure substance; it is a compound of various elements.
5. A mineral has a fixed crystal structure: Rubber does not have a fixed crystal structure.

Since rubber does not fulfill the criteria of being naturally formed, a non-organism product, a pure substance, or having a fixed crystal structure, it cannot be classified as a mineral.

1625.question: Does this passage describe the weather or the climate?
1625.hint:
Figure: Taj Mahal.
The Taj Mahal receives over two million visitors each year. It is located in northern India, where monsoon rains fall each year between June and September.
Hint: Weather is what the atmosphere is like at a certain place and time. Climate is the pattern of weather in a certain place.
1625.subject: natural science
1625.skill: Weather and climate around the world
1625.lecture:
To solve the problem, I will analyze the passage given in the context of the image to determine whether it describes weather or climate. I will do this by examining key terms that signify a pattern over time or specific atmospheric conditions at a given time.

The image depicts the Taj Mahal, an iconic white marble mausoleum located in Agra, northern India. It shows the structure with reflecting water in the foreground, indicating a calm environment.
1625.solution: The passage states that the Taj Mahal is located in northern India, where monsoon rains fall each year between June and September. The underlined section highlights a recurring pattern of precipitation over a set period annually. This indicates a long-term weather pattern typical for the region rather than the atmospheric conditions at a single moment or on a particular day. Therefore, the passage describes the climate rather than the weather.

1626.question: What is the mass of an ear of corn?
1626.subject: natural science
1626.lecture:
Measurements are written with both a number and a unit. The unit comes after the number. The unit shows what the number means.
Mass is a measurement of how much matter something contains.
There are many different units of mass. When you are using customary units, mass may be written with units of ounces, pounds, or tons.
There are 16 ounces in 1 pound and 2,000 pounds in 1 ton.
So, 1 ounce is less than 1 pound and much less than 1 ton.
A slice of bread has a mass of about 1 ounce, while a can of beans has a mass of about 1 pound. A small car has a mass of about 1 ton.
1626.solution:
The best estimate for the mass of an ear of corn is 12 ounces.
12 pounds and 12 tons are both too heavy.

1627.question: What is the capital of Delaware?
1627.subject: social science
1627.skill: Identify state capitals of the Northeast
1627.lecture:
To solve this problem, I will describe the image, consider the relevant state, and use general knowledge to identify the capital of Delaware from the given options.

The image shows a green shaded map of the United States with state boundaries delineated. Each state is depicted but not labeled.
1627.solution: To determine the capital of Delaware, I first recognize that Delaware is located on the East Coast. The capital city of Delaware, known from general knowledge, is Dover. Cross-referencing this with the given options, the capital of Delaware emerges as option (A) Dover.

1628.question: In this food web, which organism contains matter that eventually moves to the bat star?
1628.hint:
Below is a food web from an ocean ecosystem in Monterey Bay, off the coast of California.
A food web models how the matter eaten by organisms moves through an ecosystem. The arrows in a food web represent how matter moves between organisms in an ecosystem.
1628.subject: natural science
1628.lecture:
A food web is a model.
A food web shows where organisms in an ecosystem get their food. Models can make things in nature easier to understand because models can represent complex things in a simpler way. If a food web showed every organism in an ecosystem, the food web would be hard to understand. So, each food web shows how some organisms in an ecosystem can get their food.
Arrows show how matter moves.
A food web has arrows that point from one organism to another. Each arrow shows the direction that matter moves when one organism eats another organism. An arrow starts from the organism that is eaten. The arrow points to the organism that is doing the eating.
An organism in a food web can have more than one arrow pointing from it. This shows that the organism is eaten by more than one other organism in the food web.
